I Want You|Marvin Gaye|soul-blues|"a couple of weeks ago our very own mr. murray suffered a bitter anti-climax after waiting nigh on two years to hear the latest stones album. during the passing seasons
column2: while he'd been shuffling impatiently around his rock 'n' roll rest home
column3: i'd been similarly preoccupied in my soul sanatorium
column4: gnawing the woodwork and stocking up with tissues (weeping into
column5: for the use of) and bottles of something soothing
column6: anticipating this long delayed release.

column1: after a brief sob and a long draught i've calmed down sufficiently to appreciate that marvin has finally delivered the third volume of his treatise on tcb with tlc (that's taking care of business with tender loving care to you) which will serve very nicely as an epilogue to the whole endearing tale of confused-man-finds-solace-in-new-love. but the glorious fulfillment of two and a half years of boundless creativity it most certainly ain't.

column3: we'll go for it just this once more
column4: but if all you can come up with in the next 30 months is a further installment of a serial that's now signed
column6: and tied with pink ribbon
column7: then brother you be out of luck.

column2: certain traumatic events in the man's life turned him through those changes twixt 'entertainer' and 'artist.' he stopped interpreting corporation policy (which he'd been doing exceedingly well)
column3: sat back to unload his own head
column4: and re-emerged as a tangible personality
column5: troubled by the world about him
column6: seeking some kind of stability through emotional & physical love
column7: and well equipped to express those thoughts (with a little help from his friends) in words and music that enraptured anyone who was on the same wavelength.

column1: now while i'd be the first to vote self-expression above commerciality every time
column2: it seems to me that marvin is becoming too wrapped up in his own affairs. although getting down
column4: and getting it on are paramount considerations in the privacy of my own home
column5: i don't particularly want to be party to someone else's night life. not on record anyway. i want you is almost a voyeur's delight. like peeking through the windows of the gaye residence in the wee wee hours. perhaps that's your kick
column6: but personally i find it a mite frustrating.

column1: the more content he gets the less he has to say for himself. furthermore
column2: he is by his own admission a lazy man. (he was provoked into recording what's going on because of friction with his wife
column5: but test shade trees."") as a practicing sluggard i am here to testify that busy-doing-nothing is a painless philosophy for sliding through the three score years and ten and absolutely hopeless for achieving anything along the way. which is precisely why this review is one week late and this album two years late. all vocal tracks sound as if they were recorded on location in the bedroom or on the couch
column6: and the superimposed orchestral accompaniment is appropriately languid. i think the traditional expression is 'laid back.' these are so laid back they're horizontal.

column1: it seems irrelevant to start picking and choosing between them. some are long and some are short; on some he sings out loud
column2: on others he does little more than breathe heavily; a couple are purely instrumental. they are all expressions of the same mood. sensual
column4: and spaced out. i want you is simply the explorative aftermath of let's get it on. the sweet nuthin's of a drowsy

Got The Bottle Up And Gone|Sonny Boy Williamson II|soul-blues|cumberland plateau

bluegrass and string band music has one of the most fiercely loyal audiences in american music.  followers don't look at it so much as entertainment as they do a way of life.  you'll frequently see the makeup of these bands are family members
column2: and many make it their life's work.  that kind of devotion says a lot about the values they see in the music. whether it's history and tradition they hear
column3: or that they hear it as a true expression of americana
column4: the performers and their audiences are passionate. you'll find a great presentation of this in a thesis by leslie blake price entitled bluegrass nation: a historical and cultural analysis of america's truest music.

column1: any discussion of country or bluegrass music must acknow-ledge the contributions of the carter family.  they were one of the most influential groups in country music history
column2: and they moved the emphasis from hillbilly instrumentals to ""folk stories in song"".  the original group consisted of a.p.
column4: and her sister maybelle.  they influenced all that followed in country and folk music
column6: pete seeger and doc watson all the way up to bob dylan
column7: emmylou harris and ketch secor.

column1: it's unlikely that bluegrass music would exist today without the carter family's contributions. a.p. collected hundreds of appalachian folk songs and rearranged them into the classics we have today.  they recorded hundreds of songs. but ""will the circle be unbroken""
column3: and ""keep on the sunny side"" will give you a good sense of what their music did to build the folk tradition in country music.

column1: that foundation work was built-up by those who followed.  in bluegrass
column2: there are no better examples of where we are today today than earl skruggs' ""foggy mountain breakdown""
column3: the foggy mountain boys' ""rollin' in my sweet baby's arms"" or the osborne brothers' ""rocky top""
column4: but here is a short list of more recent (and also great) examples of bluegrass and string music:

column1: dailey & vincent's ""take me back (and leave me there)""

column1: country music hall of fame - nashville
the museum’s core exhibition is ""sing me back home: a journey through country music"". it's a full-immersion experience.
the first grand ole opry started here in 1925. it's almost like being in a cathedral.

bluegrass concerts are presented every month in the volcano room of cumberland caverns. they've been featured on nbc and pbs.
think of it as disneyland with a bluegrass soundtrack.
birthplace of country music museum - bristol
tells the story of the 1927 bristol sessions recordings that included the carter family and jimmie rodgers

column21: and afterwards passing by the camp might fall again into its ancient course; so that as soon as the river was thus parted in two it became fordable by both branches: and some say even that the ancient course of the river was altogether dried up. but this tale i do not admit as true
column22: for how then did they pass over the river as they went back?

column1: 77. thus the two armies contended with one another: and croesus being ill satisfied with his own army in respect of number (for the army which he had when he fought was far smaller than that of cyrus)

column6: and to summon the babylonians as well (for with these also an alliance had been concluded by him

column3: so soon as croesus marched away after the battle which had been fought in pteria

since he shall first utter speech in an evil day of misfortune.""
now when the fortress was being taken

column1: 92. now there are in hellas many other votive offerings made by croesus and not only those which have been mentioned: for first at thebes of the boeotians there is a tripod of gold
column2: which he dedicated to the ismenian apollo; then at ephesos there are the golden cows and the greater number of the pillars of the temple; and in the temple of athene pronaia at delphi a large golden shield. these were still remaining down to my own time

column5: equal in weight and similar to those at delphi. now those which he sent to delphi and to the temple of amphiaraos he dedicated of his own goods and as first-fruits of the wealth inherited from his father; but the other offerings were made of the substance of a man who was his foe
column6: who before croesus became king had been factious against him and had joined in endeavouring to make pantaleon ruler of the lydians. now pantaleon was a son of alyattes and a brother of croesus

column1: 93. of marvels to be recorded the land of lydia has no great store as compared with other lands
column2: 104 excepting the gold-dust which is carried down from tmolos; but one work it has to show which is larger far than any other except only those in egypt and babylon: for there is there the sepulchral monument of alyattes the father of croesus
column3: of which the base is made of larger stones and the rest of the monument is of earth piled up. and this was built by contributions of those who practised trade and of the artisans and the girls who plied their traffic there; and still there existed to my own time boundary-stones five in number erected upon the monument above
column4: on which were carved inscriptions telling how much of the work was done by each class; and upon measurement it was found that the work of the girls was the greatest in amount. for the daughters of the common people in lydia practice prostitution one and all
column6: continuing this until the time when they marry; and the girls give themselves away in marriage. now the circuit of the monument is six furlongs and two hundred feet
column7: 105 and the breadth is thirteen hundred feet. 106 and adjoining the monument is a great lake
column8: which the lydians say has a never-failing supply of water
column9: and it is called the lake of gyges. 107 such is the nature of this monument.

column1: 94. now the lydians have very nearly the same customs as the hellenes
column2: with the exception that they prostitute their female children; and they were the first of men
column4: who struck and used coin of gold or silver; and also they were the first retail-traders. and the lydians themselves say that the games which are now in use among them and among the hellenes were also their invention. these they say were invented among them at the same time as they colonised tyrsenia
column5: 108 and this is the account they give of them:—in the reign of atys the son of manes their king there came to be a grievous dearth over the whole of lydia; and the lydians for a time continued to endure it
column6: but afterwards
column7: as it did not cease
column8: they sought for remedies; and one devised one thing and another of them devised another thing. and then were discovered
column9: they say
column10: the ways of playing with the dice and the knucklebones and the ball
column11: and all the other games excepting draughts (for the discovery of this last is not claimed by the lydians). these games they invented as a resource against the famine
column12: and thus they used to do:—on one of the days they would play games all the time in order that they might not feel the want of food
column13: and on the next they ceased from their games and had food: and thus they went on for eighteen years. as however the evil did not slacken but pressed upon them ever more and more
column14: therefore their king divided the whole lydian people into two parts
column15: and he appointed by lot one part to remain and the other to go forth from the land; and the king appointed himself to be over that one of the parts which had the lot to stay in the land
column16: and his son to be over that which was departing; and the name of his son was tyrsenos. so the one party of them
column17: having obtained the lot to go forth from the land
column18: went down to the sea at smyrna and built ships for themselves
column19: wherein they placed all the movable goods which they had and sailed away to seek for means of living and a land to dwell in; until after passing by many nations they came at last to the land of the ombricans
column20: 109 and there they founded cities and dwell up to the present time: and changing their name they were called after the king's son who led them out from home
column21: not lydians but tyrsenians
column22: taking the name from him.

column1: the lydians then had been made subject to the persians as i say:

column2: and after this our history proceeds to inquire about cyrus
column3: who he was that destroyed the empire of croesus
column5: in what manner they obtained the lead of asia. following then the report of some of the persians
column6: —those i mean who do not desire to glorify the history of cyrus but to speak that which is in fact true
column7: —according to their report
column8: i say
column9: i shall write; but i could set forth also the other forms of the story in three several ways.

column1: the assyrians ruled upper asia 110 for five hundred and twenty years
column2: and from them the medes were the first who made revolt. these having fought for their freedom with the assyrians proved themselves good men
column3: and thus they pushed off the yoke of slavery from themselves and were set free; and after them the other nations also did the same as the medes: and when all on the continent were thus independent
column4: they returned again to despotic rule as follows:—

column1: 96. there appeared among the medes a man of great ability whose name was deïokes

column5: for they had supposed without doubt that their son had perished straightway after his birth; and they inquired in what manner he had survived. and he told them
column6: saying that before this he had not known but had been utterly in error; on the way
column7: however
column8: he had learnt all his own fortunes: for he had supposed without doubt that he was the son of the herdsman of astyages
column9: but since his journey from the city began he had learnt the whole story from those who conducted him. and he said that he had been brought up by the wife of the herdsman
column10: and continued to praise her throughout
column11: so that kyno was the chief person in his tale. and his parents took up this name from him
column12: and in order that their son might be thought by the persians to have been preserved in a more supernatural manner
column13: they set on foot a report that cyrus when he was exposed had been reared by a bitch: 132 and from that source has come this report.

column1: 123. then as cyrus grew to be a man
column2: being of all those of his age the most courageous and the best beloved
column3: harpagos sought to become his friend and sent him gifts
column4: because he desired to take vengeance on astyages. for he saw not how from himself
column5: who was in a private station
column6: punishment should come upon astyages; but when he saw cyrus growing up
column7: he endeavoured to make him an ally
column8: finding a likeness between the fortunes of cyrus and his own. and even before that time he had effected something: for astyages being harsh towards the medes
column9: harpagos communicated severally with the chief men of the medes
column10: and persuaded them that they must make cyrus their leader and cause astyages to cease from being king. when he had effected this and when all was ready
column11: then harpagos wishing to make known his design to cyrus
column12: who lived among the persians
column13: could do it no other way
column14: seeing that the roads were watched
column15: but devised a scheme as follows:—he made ready a hare
column16: and having cut open its belly but without pulling off any of the fur
column17: he put into it
column18: just as it was
column19: a piece of paper
column20: having written upon it that which he thought good; and then he sewed up again the belly of the hare
column21: and giving nets as if he were a hunter to that one of his servants whom he trusted most
column22: he sent him away to the land of the persians
column23: enjoining him by word of mouth to give the hare to cyrus
column24: and to tell him at the same time to open it with his own hands and let no one else be present when he did so.

column2: and cyrus having received from him the hare
column3: cut it open; and having found within it the paper he took and read it over. and the writing said this: ""son of cambyses
column4: over thee the gods keep guard
column5: for otherwise thou wouldst never have come to so much good fortune. do thou therefore 133 take vengeance on astyages who is thy murderer
column6: for so far as his will is concerned thou art dead
column7: but by the care of the gods and of me thou art still alive; and this i think thou hast long ago learnt from first to last
column8: both how it happened about thyself
column9: and also what things i have suffered from astyages
column10: because i did not slay thee but gave thee to the herdsman. if therefore thou wilt be guided by me
column11: thou shalt be ruler of all that land over which now astyages is ruler. persuade the persians to revolt
column12: and march any army against the medes: and whether i shall be appointed leader of the army against thee
column13: or any other of the medes who are in repute
column14: thou hast what thou desirest; for these will be the first to attempt to destroy astyages
column15: revolting from him and coming over to thy party. consider then that here at least all is ready
column16: and therefore do this and do it with speed.""

column1: 125. cyrus having heard this began to consider in what manner he might most skilfully persuade the persians to revolt
column2: and on consideration he found that this was the most convenient way
column3: and so in fact he did:—he wrote first on a paper that which he desired to write
column4: and he made an assembly of the persians. then he unfolded the paper and reading from it said that astyages appointed him commander of the persians; ""and now
column6: he continued
column7: ""i give you command to come to me each one with a reaping-hook."" cyrus then proclaimed this command. (now there are of the persians many tribes
column8: and some of them cyrus gathered together and persuaded to revolt from the medes
column9: namely those
column10: upon which all the other persians depend
column11: the pasargadai
column12: the maraphians and the maspians
column13: and of these the pasargadai are the most noble
column14: of whom also the achaimenidai are a clan
column15: whence are sprung the perseïd 134 kings. but other persian tribes there are
column16: as follows:—the panthaliaians
column17: the derusiaians and the germanians
column18: these are all tillers of the soil; and the rest are nomad tribes
column19: namely the daoi
column20: mardians
column21: dropicans and sagartians.)

column1: 126. now there was a certain region of the persian land which was overgrown with thorns
column2: extending some eighteen or twenty furlongs in each direction; and when all had come with that which they had been before commanded to bring
column3: cyrus bade them clear this region for cultivation within one day: and when the persians had achieved the task proposed
column4: then he bade them come to him on the next day bathed and clean. meanwhile cyrus
column5: having gathered together in one place all the flocks of goats and sheep and the herds of cattle belonging to his father
column6: slaughtered them and prepared with them to entertain the host of the persians
column7: and moreover with wine and other provisions of the most agreeable kind. so when the persians came on the next day
column8: he made them recline in a meadow and feasted them. and when they had finished dinner
column9: cyrus asked them whether that which they had on the former day or that which they had now seemed to them preferable. they said that the difference between them was great
column10: for the former day had for them nothing but evil
column11: and the present day nothing but good. taking up this saying cyrus proceeded to lay bare his whole design
column12: saying: ""men of the persians
column13: thus it is with you. if ye will do as i say
column14: ye have these and ten thousand other good things
column15: with no servile labour; but if ye will not do as i say
column16: ye have labours like that of yesterday innumerable. now therefore do as i say and make yourselves free: for i seem to myself to have been born by providential fortune to take these matters in hand; and i think that ye are not worse men than the medes
column17: either in other matters or in those which have to do with war. consider then that this is so
column18: and make revolt from astyages forthwith.""

column1: 127. so the persians having obtained a leader willingly attempted to set themselves free
column2: since they had already for a long time been indignant to be ruled by the medes: but when astyages heard that cyrus was acting thus
column3: he sent a messenger and summoned him; and cyrus bade the messenger report to astyages that he would be with him sooner than he would himself desire. so astyages hearing this armed all the medes
column4: and blinded by divine providence he appointed harpagos to be the leader of the army
column5: forgetting what he had done to him. then when the medes had marched out and began to fight with the persians
column6: some of them continued the battle
column7: namely those who had not been made partakers in the design
column8: while others went over to the persians; but the greater number were wilfully slack and fled.

column1: 128. so when the median army had been shamefully dispersed
column2: so soon as astyages heard of it he said
column3: threatening cyrus: ""but not even so shall cyrus at least escape punishment."" thus having spoken he first impaled the magian interpreters of dreams who had persuaded him to let cyrus go
column4: and then he armed those of the medes
column6: who had been left behind in the city. these he led out and having engaged battle with the persians he was worsted
column7: and astyages himself was taken alive
column8: and he lost also those of the medes whom he had led forth.

column1: 129. then when astyages was a prisoner
column2: harpagos came and stood near him and rejoiced over him and insulted him; and besides other things which he said to grieve him
column3: he asked him especially how it pleased him to be a slave instead of a king
column4: making reference to that dinner at which astyages had feasted him with the flesh of his own son. 135 he looking at him asked him in return whether he claimed the work of cyrus as his own deed: and harpagos said that since he had written the letter
column5: the deed was justly his. then astyages declared him to be at the same time the most unskilful and the most unjust of men; the most unskilful because
column6: when it was in his power to become king (as it was
column7: if that which had now been done was really brought about by him)
column8: he had conferred the chief power on another
column9: and the most unjust
column10: because on account of that dinner he had reduced the medes to slavery. for if he must needs confer the kingdom on some other and not keep it himself
column11: it was more just to give this good thing to one of the medes rather than to one of the persians; whereas now the medes
column12: who were guiltless of this
column13: had become slaves instead of masters
column14: and the persians who formerly were slaves of the medes had now become their masters.

column2: having been king for five-and-thirty years
column3: was thus caused to cease from being king; and the medes stooped under the yoke of the persians because of his cruelty
column4: after they had ruled asia above the river halys for one hundred and twenty-eight years
column5: except during that period for which the scythians had rule. 136 afterwards however it repented them that they had done this
column6: and they revolved from dareios
column7: and having revolted they were subdued again
column8: being conquered in a battle. at this time then
column9: i say
column10: in the reign of astyages
column11: the persians with cyrus rose up against the medes and from that time forth were rulers of asia: but as for astyages
column12: cyrus did no harm to him besides
column13: but kept him with himself until he died. thus born and bred cyrus became king; and after this he subdued croesus
column14: who was the first to begin the quarrel
column15: as i have before said; and having subdued him he then became ruler of all asia.

column3: which the persians practise:—images and temples and altars they do not account it lawful to erect
column4: nay they even charge with folly those who do these things; and this
column6: because they do not account the gods to be in the likeness of men
column7: as do the hellenes. but it is their won't to perform sacrifices to zeus going up to the most lofty of the mountains
column8: and the whole circle of the heavens they call zeus: and they sacrifice to the sun and the moon and the earth
column9: to fire and to water and to the winds: these are the only gods to whom they have sacrificed ever from the first; but they have learnt also to sacrifice to aphrodite urania
column10: having learnt it both from the assyrians and the arabians; and the assyrians call aphrodite mylitta
column11: the arabians alitta
column12: 13601 and the persians mitra.

column1: 132. now this is the manner of sacrifice for the gods aforesaid which is established among the persians:—they make no altars neither do they kindle fire; and when they mean to sacrifice they use no libation nor music of the pipe nor chaplets 137 nor meal for sprinkling; 138 but when a man wishes to sacrifice to any one of the gods
column2: he leads the animal for sacrifice to an unpolluted place and calls upon the god
column3: having his tiara 13801 wreathed round generally with a branch of myrtle. for himself alone separately the man who sacrifices may not request good things in his prayer
column4: but he prays that it may be well with all the persians and with the king; for he himself also is included of course in the whole body of persians. and when he has cut up the victim into pieces and boiled the flesh
column5: he spreads a layer of the freshest grass and especially clover
column6: upon which he places forthwith all the pieces of flesh; and when he has placed them in order
column7: a magian man stands by them and chants over them a theogony (for of this nature they say that their incantation is)
column8: seeing that without a magian it is not lawful for them to make sacrifices. then after waiting a short time the sacrificer carries away the flesh and uses it for whatever purpose he pleases.

column1: 133. and of all days their won't is to honour most that on which they were born
column2: each one: on this they think it right to set out a feast more liberal than on other days; and in this feast the wealthier of them set upon the table an ox or a horse or a camel or an ass
column4: and the poor among them set out small animals in the same way. they have few solid dishes
column5: 139 but many served up after as dessert
column6: and these not in a single course; and for this reason the persians say that the hellenes leave off dinner hungry
column7: because after dinner they have nothing worth mentioning served up as dessert
column8: whereas if any good dessert were served up they would not stop eating so soon. to wine-drinking they are very much given
column9: and it is not permitted for a man to vomit or to make water in presence of another. thus do they provide against these things; and they are won't to deliberate when drinking hard about the most important of their affairs
column10: and whatsoever conclusion has pleased them in their deliberation
column11: this on the next day
column12: when they are sober
column13: the master of the house in which they happen to be when they deliberate lays before them for discussion: and if it pleases them when they are sober also
column14: they adopt it
column15: but if it does not please them
column16: they let it go: and that on which they have had the first deliberation when they are sober
column17: they consider again when they are drinking.

column1: 134. when they meet one another in the roads
column2: by this you may discern whether those who meet are of equal rank
column3: —for instead of greeting by words they kiss one another on the mouth; but if one of them is a little inferior to the other
column4: they kiss one another on the cheeks
column5: and if one is of much less noble rank than the other
column6: he falls down before him and does worship to him. 140 and they honour of all most after themselves those nations which dwell nearest to them
column7: and next those which dwell next nearest
column8: and so they go on giving honour in proportion to distance; and they hold least in honour those who dwell furthest off from themselves
column9: esteeming themselves to be by far the best of all the human race on every point
column10: and thinking that others possess merit according to the proportion which is here stated
column11: 141 and that those who dwell furthest from themselves are the worst. and under the supremacy of the medes the various nations used also to govern one another according to the same rule as the persians observe in giving honour
column12: 142 the medes governing the whole and in particular those who dwelt nearest to themselves
column13: and these having rule over those who bordered upon them
column14: and those again over the nations that were next to them: for the race went forward thus ever from government by themselves to government through others.

column1: 135. the persians more than any other men admit foreign usages; for they both wear the median dress judging it to be more comely than their own
column2: and also for fighting the egyptian corslet: moreover they adopt all kinds of luxuries when they hear of them
column3: and in particular they have learnt from the hellenes to have commerce with boys. they marry each one several lawful wives
column4: and they get also a much larger number of concubines.

column1: 136. it is established as a sign of manly excellence next after excellence in fight
column2: to be able to show many sons; and to those who have most the king sends gifts every year: for they consider number to be a source of strength. and they educate their children
column3: beginning at five years old and going on till twenty
column6: in shooting
column7: and in speaking the truth: but before the boy is five years old he does not come into the presence of his father
column8: but lives with the women; and it is so done for this reason
column9: that if the child should die while he is being bred up
column10: he may not be the cause of any grief to his father.

column1: 137. i commend this custom of theirs
column2: and also the one which is next to be mentioned
column3: namely that neither the king himself shall put any to death for one cause alone
column4: nor any of the other persians for one cause alone shall do hurt that is irremediable to any of his own servants; but if after reckoning he finds that the wrongs done are more in number and greater than the services rendered
column5: 143 then only he gives vent to his anger. moreover they say that no one ever killed his own father or mother
column6: but whatever deeds have been done which seemed to be of this nature
column7: if examined must necessarily
column8: they say
column9: be found to be due either to changelings or to children of adulterous birth; for
column10: say they
column11: it is not reasonable to suppose that the true parent would be killed by his own son.

column1: 138. whatever things it is not lawful for them to do
column2: these it is not lawful for them even to speak of: and the most disgraceful thing in their estimation is to tell an lie
column3: and next to this to owe money
column4: this last for many other reasons
column5: but especially because it is necessary
column6: they say
column7: for him who owes money
column8: also sometimes to tell lies: and whosoever of the men of the city has leprosy or whiteness of skin
column9: he does not come into a city nor mingle with the other persians; and they say that he has these diseases because he has offended in some way against the sun: but a stranger who is taken by these diseases
column10: in many regions 144 they drive out of the country altogether
column11: and also white doves
column12: alleging against them the same cause. and into a river they neither make water nor spit
column13: neither do they wash their hands in it
column14: nor allow any other to do these things
column15: but they reverence rivers very greatly.

column1: 139. this moreover also has chanced to them
column2: which the persians have themselves failed to notice but i have not failed to do so:—their names
column3: which are formed to correspond with their bodily shapes or their magnificence of station
column4: end all with the same letter
column5: that letter which the dorians call san and the ionians sigma; with this you will find
column6: if you examine the matter
column7: that all the persian names end
column8: not some with this and others with other letters
column9: but all alike.

column1: 140. so much i am able to say for certain from my own knowledge about them: but what follows is reported about their dead as a secret mystery and not with clearness
column2: namely that the body of a persian man is not buried until it has been torn by a bird or a dog. (the magians i know for a certainty have this practice
column3: for they do it openly.) however that may be
column4: the persians cover the body with wax and then bury it in the earth. now the magians are distinguished in many ways from other men
column5: as also from the priests in egypt: for these last esteem it a matter of purity to kill no living creature except the animals which they sacrifice; but the magians kill with their own hands all creatures except dogs and men
column6: and they even make this a great end to aim at
column7: killing both ants and serpents and all other creeping and flying things. about this custom then be it as it was from the first established; and i return now to the former narrative. 145

column2: as soon as the lydians had been subdued by the persians
column3: sent messengers to cyrus at sardis
column4: desiring to be his subjects on the same terms as they had been subjects of croesus. and when he heard that which they proposed to him
column5: he spoke to them a fable
column6: saying that a certain player on the pipe saw fishes in the sea and played on his pipe
column7: supposing that they would come out to land; but being deceived in his expectation
column8: he took a casting-net and enclosed a great multitude of the fishes and drew them forth from the water: and when he saw them leaping about
column9: he said to the fishes: ""stop dancing i pray you now
column10: seeing that ye would not come out and dance before when i piped."" cyrus spoke this fable to the ionians and aiolians for this reason
column11: because the ionians had refused to comply before
column12: when cyrus himself by a messenger requested them to revolt from croesus
column13: while now when the conquest had been made they were ready to submit to cyrus. thus he said to them in anger
column14: and the ionians
column15: when they heard this answer brought back to their cities
column16: put walls round about them severally
column17: and gathered together to the panionion
column18: all except the men of miletos
column19: for with these alone cyrus had sworn an agreement on the same terms as the lydians had granted. the rest of the ionians resolved by common consent to send messengers to sparta
column20: to ask the spartans to help the ionians.

column1: 142. these ionians to whom belongs the panionion had the fortune to build their cities in the most favourable position for climate and seasons of any men whom we know: for neither the regions above ionia nor those below
column2: neither those towards the east nor those towards the west
column3: 146 produce the same results as ionia itself
column4: the regions in the one direction being oppressed by cold and moisture
column5: and those in the other by heat and drought. and these do not use all the same speech
column6: but have four different variations of language. 147 first of their cities on the side of the south lies miletos
column7: and next to it myus and priene. these are settlements made in caria
column8: and speak the same language with one another; and the following are in lydia
column9: —ephesos
column10: colophon
column11: lebedos
column12: teos
column13: clazomenai
column14: phocaia: these cities resemble not at all those mentioned before in the speech which they use
column15: but they agree one with another. there remain besides three ionian cities
column16: of which two are established in the islands of samos and chios
column17: and one is built upon the mainland
column18: namely erythrai: now the men of chios and of erythrai use the same form of language
column19: but the samians have one for themselves alone. thus there result four separate forms of language.

column1: 143. of these ionians then those of miletos were sheltered from danger
column2: since they had sworn an agreement; and those of them who lived in islands had no cause for fear
column3: for the phenicians were not yet subjects of the persians and the persians themselves were not sea-men. now these 148 were parted off from the other ionians for no other reason than this:—the whole hellenic nation was at that time weak
column4: but of all its races the ionian was much the weakest and of least account: except athens
column6: it had no considerable city. now the other ionians
column7: and among them the athenians
column8: avoided the name
column9: not wishing to be called ionians
column10: nay even now i perceive that the greater number of them are ashamed of the name: but these twelve cities not only prided themselves on the name but established a temple of their own
column11: to which they gave the name of panionion
column12: and they made resolution not to grant a share in it to any other ionians (nor indeed did any ask to share it except those of smyrna);

column2: just as the dorians of that district which is now called the five cities 149 but was formerly called the six cities
column3: 150 take care not to admit any of the neighbouring dorians to the temple of triopion
column4: and even exclude from sharing in it those of their own body who commit any offence as regards the temple. for example
column5: in the games of the triopian apollo they used formerly to set bronze tripods as prizes for the victors
column6: and the rule was that those who received them should not carry them out of the temple but dedicate them then and there to the god. there was a man then of halicarnassos
column7: whose name was agasicles
column8: who being a victor paid no regard to this rule
column9: but carried away the tripod to his own house and hung it up there upon a nail. on this ground the other five cities
column10: lindos
column11: ialysos and cameiros
column12: cos and cnidos
column13: excluded the sixth city halicarnassos from sharing in the temple.

column1: 145. upon these they laid this penalty: but as for the ionians
column2: i think that the reason why they made of themselves twelve cities and would not receive any more into their body
column3: was because when they dwelt in peloponnesus there were of them twelve divisions
column4: just as now there are twelve divisions of the achaians who drove the ionians out: for first
column5: (beginning from the side of sikyon) comes pellene
column6: then aigeira and aigai
column7: in which last is the river crathis with a perpetual flow (whence the river of the same name in italy received its name)
column8: and bura and helike
column9: to which the ionians fled for refuge when they were worsted by the achaians in fight
column10: and aigion and rhypes and patreis and phareis and olenos
column11: where is the great river peiros
column12: and dyme and tritaieis
column13: of which the last alone has an inland position. 151 these form now twelve divisions of the achaians
column14: and in former times they were divisions of the ionians.

column1: 146. for this reason then the ionians also made for themselves twelve cities; for at any rate to say that these are any more ionians than the other ionians
column2: or have at all a nobler descent
column4: considering that a large part of them are abantians from euboea
column5: who have no share even in the name of ionia
column6: and minyai of orchomenos have been mingled with them
column7: and cadmeians and dryopians and phokians who seceded from their native state and molossians and pelasgians of arcadia and dorians of epidauros and many other races have been mingled with them; and those of them who set forth to their settlements from the city hall of athens and who esteem themselves the most noble by descent of the ionians
column8: these
column9: i say
column10: brought no women with them to their settlement
column11: but took carian women
column12: whose parents they slew: and on account of this slaughter these women laid down for themselves a rule
column13: imposing oaths on one another
column14: and handed it on to their daughters
column15: that they should never eat with their husbands
column16: nor should a wife call her own husband by name
column17: for this reason
column18: because the ionians had slain their fathers and husbands and children and then having done this had them to wife. this happened at miletos.

column1: 147. moreover some of them set lykian kings over them
column3: while others were ruled by cauconians of pylos
column4: descendants of codros the son of melanthos
column5: and others again by princes of the two races combined. since however these hold on to the name more than the other ionians
column6: let them be called
column7: if they will
column8: the ionians of truly pure descent; but in fact all are ionians who have their descent from athens and who keep the feast of apaturia; and this all keep except the men of ephesos and colophon: for these alone of all the ionians do not keep the apaturia
column9: and that on the ground of some murder committed.

column1: 148. now the panionion is a sacred place on the north side of mycale
column2: set apart by common agreement of the ionians for poseidon of helike 152; and this mycale is a promontory of the mainland running out westwards towards samos
column3: where the ionians gathering together from their cities used to hold a festival which they called the panionia. (and not only the feasts of the ionians but also those of all the hellenes equally are subject to this rule
column4: that their names all end in the same letter
column5: just like the names of the persians.) 153

column1: these then are the ionian cities:

column2: and those of aiolia are as follows:—kyme
column6: temnos
column7: killa
column8: notion
column9: aigiroëssa
column10: pitane
column11: aigaiai
column12: myrina
column13: gryneia; these are the ancient cities of the aiolians
column14: eleven in number
column15: since one
column16: smyrna
column17: was severed from them by the ionians; for these cities
column18: that is those on the mainland
column19: used also formerly to be twelve in number. and these aiolians had the fortune to settle in a land which is more fertile than that of the ionians but in respect of climate less favoured. 154

column1: 150. now the aiolians lost smyrna in the following manner:—certain men of colophon
column2: who had been worsted in party strife and had been driven from their native city
column3: were received there for refuge: and after this the colophonian exiles watched for a time when the men of smyrna were celebrating a festival to dionysos outside the walls
column4: and then they closed the gates against them and got possession of the city. after this
column5: when the whole body of aiolians came to the rescue
column6: they made an agreement that the ionians should give up the movable goods
column7: and that on this condition the aiolians should abandon smyrna. when the men of smyrna had done this
column8: the remaining eleven cities divided them amongst themselves and made them their own citizens.

column1: 151. these then are the aiolian cities upon the mainland
column2: with the exception of those situated on mount ida
column3: for these are separate from the rest. and of those which are in the islands
column5: for the sixth which was situated in lesbos
column6: namely arisba
column7: was enslaved by the men of methymna
column8: though its citizens were of the same race as they; and in tenedos there is one city
column9: and another in what are called the ""hundred isles."" now the lesbians and the men of tenedos
column10: like those ionians who dwelt in the islands
column11: had no cause for fear; but the remaining cities came to a common agreement to follow the ionians whithersoever they should lead.

column1: 152. now when the messengers from the ionians and aiolians came to sparta (for this business was carried out with speed)
column2: they chose before all others to speak for them the phocaian
column3: whose name was pythermos. he then put upon him a purple cloak
column4: in order that as many as possible of the spartans might hear of it and come together
column5: and having been introduced before the assembly 155 he spoke at length
column6: asking the spartans to help them. the lacedemonians however would not listen to him
column7: but resolved on the contrary not to help the ionians. so they departed
column8: and the lacedemonians
column9: having dismissed the messengers of the ionians
column10: sent men notwithstanding in a ship of fifty oars
column11: to find out
column12: as i imagine
column13: about the affairs of cyrus and about ionia. these when they came to phocaia sent to sardis the man of most repute among them
column14: whose name was lacrines
column15: to report to cyrus the saying of the lacedemonians
column16: bidding him do hurt to no city of the hellas
column17: since they would not permit it.

column1: 153. when the herald had spoken thus
column2: cyrus is said to have asked those of the hellenes whom he had with him
column3: what men the lacedemonians were and how many in number
column4: that they made this proclamation to him; and hearing their answer he said to the spartan herald: ""never yet did i fear men such as these
column5: who have a place appointed in the midst of their city where they gather together and deceive one another by false oaths: and if i continue in good health
column6: not the misfortunes of the ionians will be for them a subject of talk
column7: but rather their own."" these words cyrus threw out scornfully with reference to the hellenes in general
column8: because they have got for themselves 156 markets and practise buying and selling there; for the persians themselves are not won't to use markets nor have they any market-place at all. after this he entrusted sardis to tabalos a persian
column9: and the gold both of croesus and of the other lydians he gave to pactyas a lydian to take charge of
column10: and himself marched away to agbatana
column11: taking with him croesus and making for the present no account of the ionians. for babylon stood in his way still
column12: as also the bactrian nation and the sacans and the egyptians; and against these he meant to make expeditions himself
column13: while sending some other commander about the ionians.

column1: 154. but when cyrus had marched away from sardis
column2: pactyas caused the lydians to revolt from tabalos and from cyrus. this man went down to the sea
column3: and having in his possession all the gold that there had been in sardis
column4: he hired for himself mercenaries and persuaded the men of the sea-coast to join his expedition. so he marched on sardis and besieged tabalos
column5: having shut himself up in the citadel.

column2: cyrus said to croesus as follows: ""croesus
column3: what end shall i find of these things which are coming to pass? the lydians will not cease as it seems
column4: from giving trouble to me and from having it themselves. i doubt me if it were not best 157 to sell them all as slaves; for as it is
column5: i see that i have done in like manner as if one should slay the father and then spare his sons: just so i took prisoner and am carrying away thee
column6: who wert much more than the father of the lydians
column7: while to the lydians themselves i delivered up their city; and can i feel surprise after this that they have revolted from me?"" thus he said what was in his mind
column8: but croesus answered him as follows
column9: fearing lest he should destroy sardis: ""o king
column10: that which thou hast said is not without reason; but do not thou altogether give vent to thy wrath
column11: nor destroy an ancient city which is guiltless both of the former things and also of those which have come to pass now: for as to the former things it was i who did them and i bear the consequences heaped upon my head; 158 and as for what is now being done
column12: since the wrongdoer is pactyas to whom thou didst entrust the charge of sardis
column13: let him pay the penalty. but the lydians i pray thee pardon
column14: and lay upon them commands as follows
column15: in order that they may not revolt nor be a cause of danger to thee:—send to them and forbid them to possess weapons of war
column16: but bid them on the other hand put on tunics under their outer garments and be shod with buskins
column17: and proclaim to them that they train their sons to play the lyre and the harp and to be retail-dealers; and soon thou shalt see
column18: o king
column19: that they have become women instead of men
column20: so that there will be no fear that they will revolt from thee.""

column4: perceiving that this was better for the lydians than to be reduced to slavery and sold; for he knew that if he did not offer a sufficient reason
column5: he would not persuade cyrus to change his mind
column6: and he feared lest at some future time

column1: 157. having given this charge upon the road
column2: he continued his march to the native land of the persians; but pactyas hearing that an army was approaching to fight against him was struck with fear and fled away forthwith to kyme. then mazares the mede marched upon sardis with a certain portion of the army of cyrus
column3: and as he did not find pactyas or his followers any longer at sardis
column4: he first compelled the lydians to perform the commands of cyrus
column5: and by his commands the lydians changed the whole manner of their life. after this mazares proceeded to send messengers to kyme bidding them give up pactyas: and the men of kyme resolved to refer to the god at branchidai the question what counsel they should follow. for there was there an oracle established of old time
column6: which all the ionians and aiolians were won't to consult; and this place is in the territory of miletos above the port of panormos.

column1: 158. so the men of kyme sent messengers to the branchidai 159 to inquire of the god

column3: the answer was given them that they should deliver up pactyas to the persians: and the men of kyme

column7: a man of repute among the citizens
column8: stopped the men of kyme from doing so

column2: aristodicos stood forth from the rest and consulted the oracle
column4: 160 there came to us a suppliant for protection pactyas the lydian
column5: flying from a violent death at the hands of the persians
column6: and they demand him from us
column7: bidding the men of kyme give him up. but we

column9: yet have not ventured up to this time to deliver to them the suppliant

column11: saying which of the two things we ought to do."" he thus inquired
column12: but the god again declared to them the same answer
column13: bidding them deliver up pactyas to the persians. upon this aristodicos with deliberate purpose did as follows:—he went all round the temple destroying the nests of the sparrows 161 and of all the other kinds of birds which had been hatched on the temple: and while he was doing this
column14: it is said that a voice came from the inner shrine directed to aristodicos and speaking thus: ""thou most impious of men
column15: why dost thou dare to do this? dost thou carry away by force from my temple the suppliants for my protection?"" and aristodicos
column16: it is said
column17: not being at all at a loss replied to this: ""lord

column1: 160. when the men of kyme heard this saying reported

column3: they sent him away to mytilene. those of mytilene however
column4: when mazares sent messages to them
column5: were preparing to deliver up pactyas for a price

column10: (now this atarneus is a region of mysia 162 opposition lesbos). so the persians having received pactyas kept him under guard
column11: meaning to produce him before cyrus. and a long time elapsed during which none of the chians either used barley-meal grown in this region of atarneus

column1: 161. the men of chios had then delivered up pactyas; and after this mazares made expedition against those who had joined in besieging tabalos: and first he reduced to slavery those of priene

column3: and magnesia in the same manner: and straightway after this he fell sick and died.

column2: harpagos came down to take his place in command
column3: being also a mede by race (this was the man whom the king of the medes astyages feasted with the unlawful banquet
column4: and who helped to give the kingdom to cyrus). this man
column5: being appointed commander then by cyrus
column6: came to ionia and proceeded to take the cities by throwing up mounds against them: for when he had enclosed any people within their walls
column7: then he threw up mounds against the walls and took their city by storm; and the first city of ionia upon which he made an attempt was phocaia.

column1: 163. now these phocaians were the first of the hellenes who made long voyages
column2: and these are they who discovered the adriatic and tyrsenia and iberia and tartessos: and they made voyages not in round ships
column3: but in vessels of fifty oars. these came to tartessos and became friends with the king of the tartessians whose name was arganthonios: he was ruler of the tartessians for eighty years and lived in all one hundred and twenty. with this man
column5: the phocaians became so exceedingly friendly
column6: that first he bade them leave ionia and dwell wherever they desired in his own land; and as he did not prevail upon the phocaians to do this
column7: afterwards
column8: hearing from them of the mede how his power was increasing
column9: he gave them money to build a wall about their city: and he did this without sparing
column10: for the circuit of the wall is many furlongs 163 in extent
column11: and it is built all of large stones closely fitted together.

column1: 164. the wall of the phocaians was made in this manner: and harpagos having marched his army against them began to besiege them
column2: at the same time holding forth to them proposals and saying that it was enough to satisfy him if the phocaians were willing to throw down one battlement of their wall and dedicate one single house. 164 but the phocaians
column3: being very greatly grieved at the thought of subjection
column4: said that they wished to deliberate about the matter for one day and after that they would give their answer; and they asked him to withdraw his army from the wall while they were deliberating. harpagos said that he knew very well what they were meaning to do
column5: nevertheless he was willing to allow them to deliberate. so in the time that followed
column6: when harpagos had withdrawn his army from the wall
column7: the phocaians drew down their fifty-oared galleys to the sea
column8: put into them their children and women and all their movable goods
column9: and besides them the images out of the temples and the other votive offerings except such as were made of bronze or stone or consisted of paintings
column10: all the rest
column11: i say
column12: they put into the ships
column13: and having embarked themselves they sailed towards chios; and the persians obtained possession of phocaia
column14: the city being deserted of the inhabitants.

column2: since the men of chios would not sell them at their request the islands called oinussai
column3: from the fear lest these islands might be made a seat of trade and their island might be shut out

column6: (now arganthonios by that time was dead). and when they were setting out for kyrnos they first sailed to phocaia and slaughtered the persian garrison
column7: to whose charge harpagos had delivered the city; then after they had achieved this they made solemn imprecations on any one of them who should be left behind from their voyage
column8: and moreover they sank a mass of iron in the sea and swore that not until that mass should appear again on the surface 166 would they return to phocaia. however as they were setting forth to kyrnos

column2: for five years they dwelt together with those who had come thither before

column8: and came to meet the enemy in that which is called the sardinian sea: and when they encountered one another in the sea-fight the phocaians won a kind of cadmean victory

column3: proceeded to march against the carians and caunians and lykians
column4: taking also ionians and aiolians to help him. of these the carians came to the mainland from the islands; for being of old time subjects of minos and being called leleges
column5: they used to dwell in the islands
column6: paying no tribute
column7: so far back as i am able to arrive by hearsay
column8: but whenever minos required it
column9: they used to supply his ships with seamen: and as minos subdued much land and was fortunate in his fighting
column10: the carian nation was of all nations by much the most famous at that time together with him. and they produced three inventions of which the hellenes adopted the use; that is to say
column11: the carians were those who first set the fashion of fastening crests on helmets
column12: and of making the devices which are put onto shields

column16: and so they came to the mainland. with respect to the carians the cretans relate that it happened thus; the carians themselves however do not agree with this account

column19: in which the mysians and lydians share as being brother races of the carians

column21: but those who being of another race have come to speak the same language as the carians
column22: these have no share in it.

column1: 172. it seems to me however that the caunians are dwellers there from the beginning
column2: though they say themselves that they came from crete: but they have been assimilated to the carian race in language
column3: or else the carians to the caunian race
column4: i cannot with certainty determine which. they have customs however in which they differ very much from all other men as well as from the carians; for example the fairest thing in their estimation is to meet together in numbers for drinking
column5: according to equality of age or friendship
column6: both men
column7: women
column8: and children; and again when they had founded temples for foreign deities
column9: afterwards they changed their purpose and resolved to worship only their own native gods
column10: and the whole body of caunian young men put on their armour and made pursuit as far as the borders of the calyndians
column11: beating the air with their spears; and they said that they were casting the foreign gods out of the land. such are the customs which these have.

column1: 173. the lykians however have sprung originally from crete (for in old time the whole of crete was possessed by barbarians): and when the sons of europa
column3: came to be at variance in crete about the kingdom
column4: minos having got the better in the strife of parties drove out both sarpedon himself and those of his party: and they having been expelled came to the land of milyas in asia
column5: for the land which now the lykians inhabit was anciently called milyas
column6: and the milyans were then called solymoi. now while sarpedon reigned over them
column7: they were called by the name which they had when they came thither
column8: and by which the lykians are even now called by the neighbouring tribes
column9: namely termilai; but when from athens lycos the son of pandion came to the land of the termilai and to sarpedon
column10: he too having been driven out by his brother namely aigeus
column11: then by the name taken from lycos they were called after a time lykians. the customs which these have are partly cretan and partly carian; but one custom they have which is peculiar to them
column12: and in which they agree with no other people
column13: that is they call themselves by their mothers and not by their fathers; and if one asks his neighbour who he is
column14: he will state his parentage on the mother's side and enumerate his mother's female ascendants: and if a woman who is a citizen marry a slave
column15: the children are accounted to be of gentle birth; but if a man who is a citizen
column16: though he were the first man among them
column17: have a slave for wife or concubine
column18: the children are without civil rights.

column1: 174. now the carians were reduced to subjection by harpagos without any brilliant deed displayed either by the carians themselves or by those of the hellenes who dwell in this land. of these last there are besides others the men of cnidos
column3: whose land runs out into the sea
column4: 173 being in fact the region which is called triopion
column5: beginning from the peninsula of bybassos: and since all the land of cnidos except a small part is washed by the sea (for the part of it which looks towards the north is bounded by the gulf of keramos
column6: and that which looks to the south by the sea off syme and rhodes)
column7: therefore the men of cnidos began to dig through this small part
column8: which is about five furlongs across
column9: while harpagos was subduing ionia
column10: desiring to make their land an island: and within the isthmus all was theirs
column11: 174 for where the territory of cnidos ends in the direction of the mainland
column12: here is the isthmus which they were digging across. and while the cnidians were working at it with a great number of men
column13: it was perceived that the men who worked suffered injury much more than might have been expected and in a more supernatural manner
column14: both in other parts of their bodies and especially in their eyes
column15: when the rock was being broken up; so they sent men to ask the oracle at delphi what the cause of the difficulty was. and the pythian prophetess
column16: as the men of cnidos themselves report
column17: gave them this reply in trimeter verse:—

column1: zeus would have made your land an island
when the pythian prophetess had given this oracle
column2: the men of cnidos not only ceased from their digging but delivered themselves to harpagos without resistance
column3: when he came against them with his army.

column2: who dwelt in the inland country above halicarnassos; and among these

column4: the priestess of athene has a great beard: this befell them three times. these of all about caria were the only men who held out for any time against harpagos
column5: and they gave him trouble more than any other people
column6: having fortified a mountain called lide.

column1: 176. after a time the pedasians were conquered; and the lykians
column2: when harpagos marched his army into the plain of xanthos
column3: came out against him 175 and fought
column5: and displayed proofs of valour; but being defeated and confined within their city
column6: they gathered together into the citadel their wives and their children
column7: their property and their servants
column8: and after that they set fire to this citadel
column9: so that it was all in flames
column10: and having done so and sworn terrible oaths with one another

column12: that is to say all the men of xanthos: and of the xanthians who now claim to be lykians the greater number have come in from abroad
column13: except only eighty households; but these eighty households happened at that time to be away from their native place

column1: 177. so harpagos was conquering the coast regions of asia; and cyrus himself meanwhile was doing the same in the upper parts of it
column2: subduing every nation and passing over none. now most of these actions i shall pass over in silence
column3: but the undertakings which gave him trouble more than the rest and which are the most worthy of note
column4: of these i shall make mention.

column2: so soon as he had made subject to himself all other parts of the mainland
column3: proceeded to attack the assyrians. now assyria has doubtless many other great cities
column4: but the most famous and the strongest
column5: and the place where the seat of their monarchy had been established after nineveh was destroyed
column6: was babylon; which was a city such as i shall say.—it lies in a great plain
column7: and in size it is such that each face measures one hundred and twenty furlongs
column8: 177 the shape of the whole being square; thus the furlongs of the circuit of the city amount in all to four hundred and eighty. such is the size of the city of babylon
column9: and it had a magnificence greater than all other cities of which we have knowledge. first there runs round it a trench deep and broad and full of water; then a wall fifty royal cubits in thickness and two hundred cubits in height: now the royal cubit is larger by three fingers than the common cubit. 178

column1: 179. i must also tell in addition to this for what purpose the earth was used
column2: which was taken out of the trench
column3: and in what manner the wall was made. as they dug the trench they made the earth which was carried out of the excavation into bricks
column4: and having moulded enough bricks they baked them in kilns; and then afterwards
column5: using hot asphalt for mortar and inserting reed mats at every thirty courses of brickwork
column6: they built up first the edges of the trench and then the wall itself in the same manner: and at the top of the wall along the edges they built chambers of one story facing one another; and between the rows of chambers they left space to drive a four-horse chariot. in the circuit of the wall there are set a hundred gates made of bronze throughout
column7: and the gate-posts and lintels likewise. now there is another city distant from babylon a space of eight days' journey
column8: of which the name is is; and there is a river there of no great size
column9: and the name of the river is also is
column10: and it sends its stream into the river euphrates. this river is throws up together with its water lumps of asphalt in great abundance
column11: and thence was brought the asphalt for the wall of babylon.

column1: 180. babylon then was walled in this manner; and there are two divisions of the city; for a river whose name is euphrates parts it in the middle. this flows from the land of the armenians and is large and deep and swift
column2: and it flows out into the erythraian sea. the wall then on each side has its bends 179 carried down to the river
column3: and from this point the return walls stretch along each bank of the stream in the form of a rampart of baked bricks: and the city itself is full of houses of three and four stories
column4: and the roads by which it is cut up run in straight lines
column5: including the cross roads which lead to the river; and opposite to each road there were set gates in the rampart which ran along the river
column6: in many in number as the ways
column7: 180 and these also were of bronze and led like the ways 181 to the river itself.

column1: 181. this wall then which i have mentioned is as it were a cuirass 182 for the town
column2: and another wall runs round within it
column3: not much weaker for defence than the first but enclosing a smaller space. 183and in each division of the city was a building in the midst
column4: in the one the king's palace of great extent and strongly fortified round
column5: and in the other the temple of zeus belos with bronze gates
column6: and this exists still up to my time and measures two furlongs each way
column7: 184 being of a square shape: and in the midst of the temple 185 is built a solid tower measuring a furlong both in length and in breadth
column8: and on this tower another tower has been erected
column9: and another again upon this
column10: and so on up to the number of eight towers. an ascent to these has been built running outside round about all the towers; and when one reaches about the middle of the ascent one finds a stopping-place and seats to rest upon
column11: on which those who ascend sit down and rest: and on the top of the last tower there is a large cell
column12: 186and in the cell a large couch is laid
column13: well covered
column14: and by it is placed a golden table: and there is no image there set up nor does any human being spend the night there except only one woman of the natives of the place
column15: whomsoever the god shall choose from all the woman
column16: as say the chaldeans who are the priests of this god.

column2: but i do not believe them
column3: that the god himself comes often to the cell and rests upon the couch
column4: as happens likewise in the egyptian thebes according to the report of the egyptians
column5: for there also a woman sleeps in the temple of the theban zeus (and both these women are said to abstain from commerce with men)
column6: and as happens also with the prophetess 187 of the god in patara of lykia
column7: whenever there is one
column8: for there is not always an oracle there
column9: but whenever there is one
column10: then she is shut up during the nights in the temple within the cell.

column1: 183. there is moreover in the temple at babylon another cell below
column2: wherein is a great image of zeus sitting
column4: and by it is placed a large table of gold
column5: and his footstool and seat are of gold also; and
column6: as the chaldeans reported
column7: the weight of the gold of which these things are made is eight hundred talents. outside this cell is an altar of gold; and there is also another altar of great size
column8: where full-grown animals 188 are sacrificed
column9: whereas on the golden altar it is not lawful to sacrifice any but young sucklings only: and also on the larger altar the chaldeans offer one thousand talents of frankincense every year at the time when they celebrate the feast in honour of this god. there was moreover in these precincts still remaining at the time of cyrus
column10: 189 a statue twelve cubits high
column11: of gold and solid. this i did not myself see
column12: but that which is related by the chaldeans i relate. against this statue dareios the son of hystaspes formed a design
column13: but he did not venture to take it: it was taken however by xerxes the son of dareios
column14: who also killed the priest when he forbade him to meddle with the statue. this temple
column15: then
column16: is thus adorned with magnificence
