column3: of whom i shall make mention in the assyrian history
column4: and who added improvement to the walls and temples
column5: there were also two who were women. of these
column6: the one who ruled first
column7: named semiramis
column8: who lived five generations before the other
column9: produced banks of earth in the plain which are a sight worth seeing; and before this the river used to flood like a sea over the whole plain.

column1: 185. the queen who lived after her time
column3: was wiser than she who had reigned before; and in the first place she left behind her monuments which i shall tell of; then secondly
column4: seeing that the monarchy of the medes was great and not apt to remain still
column5: but that besides other cities even nineveh had been captured by it
column6: she made provision against it in so far as she was able. first
column7: as regards the river euphrates which flows through the midst of their city
column8: whereas before this it flowed straight
column9: she by digging channels above made it so winding that it actually comes three times in its course to one of the villages in assyria; and the name of the village to which the euphrates comes is ardericca; and at this day those who travel from this sea of ours to babylon
column10: in their voyage down the river euphrates 18901 arrive three times at this same village and on three separate days. this she did thus; and she also piled up a mound along each bank of the river
column11: which is worthy to cause wonder for its size and height: and at a great distance above babylon
column12: she dug a basin for a lake
column13: which she caused to extend along at a very small distance from the river
column14: 190 excavating it everywhere of such depth as to come to water
column15: and making the extent such that the circuit of it measured four hundred and twenty furlongs: and the earth which was dug out of this excavation she used up by piling it in mounds along the banks of the river: and when this had been dug by her she brought stones and set them all round it as a facing wall. both these two things she did
column16: that is she made the river to have a winding course
column17: and she made the place which was dug out all into a swamp
column18: in order that the river might run more slowly
column19: having its force broken by going round many bends
column20: and that the voyages might be winding to babylon
column21: and after the voyages there might succeed a long circuit of the pool. these works she carried out in that part where the entrance to the country was
column22: and the shortest way to it from media
column23: so that the medes might not have dealings with her kingdom and learn of her affairs.

column1: 186. these defences she cast round her city from the depth; and she made the following addition which was dependent upon them:—the city was in two divisions
column2: and the river occupied the space between; and in the time of the former rulers
column3: when any one wished to pass over from the one division to the other
column4: he had to pass over in a boat
column6: as i imagine
column7: was troublesome: she however made provision also for this; for when she was digging the basin for the lake she left this other monument of herself derived from the same work
column8: that is
column9: she caused stones to be cut of very great length
column10: and when the stones were prepared for her and the place had been dug out
column11: she turned aside the whole stream of the river into the place which she had been digging; and while this was being filled with water
column12: the ancient bed of the river being dried up in the meantime
column13: she both built up with baked bricks after the same fashion as the wall the edges of the river
column14: where it flows through the city
column15: and the places of descent leading from the small gateways to the river; and also about the middle of the city
column16: as i judge
column17: with the stones which she had caused to be dug out she proceeded to build a bridge
column18: binding together the stones with iron and lead: and upon the top she laid squared timbers across
column19: to remain there while it was daytime
column20: over which the people of babylon made the passage across; but at night they used to take away these timbers for this reason
column21: namely that they might not go backwards and forwards by night and steal from one another: and when the place dug out had been made into a lake full of water by the river
column22: and at the same time the bridge had been completed
column23: then she conducted the euphrates back into its ancient channel from the lake
column24: and so the place dug out being made into a swamp was thought to have served a good purpose
column25: and there had been a bridge set up for the men of the city.

column1: 187. this same queen also contrived a snare of the following kind:—over that gate of the city through which the greatest number of people passed she set up for herself a tomb above the very gate itself. and on the tomb she engraved writing which said thus: ""if any of the kings of babylon who come after me shall be in want of wealth
column2: let him open my tomb and take as much as he desires; but let him not open it for any other cause
column3: if he be not in want; for that will not be well."" 191 this tomb was undisturbed until the kingdom came to dareios; but to dareios it seemed that it was a monstrous thing not to make any use of this gate
column5: when there was money lying there
column6: not to take it
column7: considering that the money itself invited him to do so. now the reason why he would not make any use of this gate was because the corpse would have been above his head as he drove through. he then
column8: i say
column9: opened the tomb and found not indeed money but the corpse
column10: with writing which said thus: ""if thou hadst not been insatiable of wealth and basely covetous
column11: thou wouldest not have opened the resting-places of the dead.""

column1: 188. this queen then is reported to have been such as i have described: and it was the son of this woman
column2: bearing the same name as his father
column4: and being ruler over the assyrians
column5: against whom cyrus was marching. now the great king makes his marches not only well furnished 192 from home with provisions for his table and with cattle
column6: but also taking with him water from the river choaspes
column7: which flows by susa
column8: of which alone and of no other river the king drinks: and of this water of the choaspes boiled
column9: a very great number of waggons
column10: four-wheeled and drawn by mules
column11: carry a supply in silver vessels
column12: and go with him wherever he may march at any time.

column1: 189. now when cyrus on his way towards babylon arrived at the river gyndes
column2: —of which river the springs are in the mountains of the matienians
column3: and it flows through the dardanians and runs into another river
column5: which flowing by the city of opis runs out into the erythraian sea
column6: —when cyrus
column7: i say
column8: was endeavouring to cross this river gyndes
column9: which is a navigable stream
column10: then one of his sacred white horses in high spirit and wantonness went into the river and endeavoured to cross
column11: but the stream swept it under water and carried it off forthwith. and cyrus was greatly moved with anger against the river for having done thus insolently
column12: and he threatened to make it so feeble that for the future even women could cross it easily without wetting the knee. so after this threat he ceased from his march against babylon and divided his army into two parts; and having divided it he stretched lines and marked out straight channels
column13: 193 one hundred and eighty on each bank of the gyndes
column14: directed every way
column15: and having disposed his army along them he commanded them to dig: so
column16: as a great multitude was working
column17: the work was completed indeed
column18: but they spent the whole summer season at this spot working.

column1: 190. when cyrus had taken vengeance on the river gyndes by dividing it into three hundred and sixty channels
column2: and when the next spring was just beginning
column3: then at length he continued his advance upon babylon: and the men of babylon had marched forth out of their city and were awaiting him. so when in his advance he came near to the city
column4: the babylonians joined battle with him
column5: and having been worsted in the fight they were shut up close within their city. but knowing well even before this that cyrus was not apt to remain still
column6: and seeing him lay hands on every nation equally
column7: they had brought in provisions beforehand 194 for very many years. so while these made no account of the siege
column8: cyrus was in straits what to do
column9: for much time went by and his affairs made no progress onwards.

column2: whether it was some other man who suggested it to him when he was in a strait what to do
column3: or whether he of himself perceived what he ought to do
column4: he did as follows:—the main body of his army 195 he posted at the place where the river runs into the city
column5: and then again behind the city he set others
column6: where the river issues forth from the city; and he proclaimed to his army that so soon as they should see that the stream had become passable
column7: they should enter by this way into the city. having thus set them in their places and in this manner exhorted them he marched away himself with that part of his army which was not fit for fighting: and when he came to the lake
column8: cyrus also did the same things which the queen of the babylonians had done as regards the river and the lake; that is to say
column9: he conducted the river by a channel into the lake
column10: which was at that time a swamp
column11: and so made the former course of the river passable by the sinking of the stream. when this had been done in such a manner
column12: the persians who had been posted for this very purpose entered by the bed of the river euphrates into babylon
column13: the stream having sunk so far that it reached about to the middle of a man's thigh. now if the babylonians had had knowledge of it beforehand or had perceived that which was being done by cyrus
column14: they would have allowed 196 the persians to enter the city and then destroyed them miserably; for if they had closed all the gates that led to the river and mounted themselves upon the ramparts which were carried along the banks of the stream
column15: they would have caught them as it were in a fish-wheal: but as it was
column16: the persians came upon them unexpectedly; and owing to the size of the city (so it is said by those who dwell there) after those about the extremities of the city had suffered capture
column17: those babylonians who dwelt in the middle did not know that they had been captured; but as they chanced to be holding a festival
column18: they went on dancing and rejoicing during this time until they learnt the truth only too well.

column1: babylon then had thus been taken for the first time:

column2: and as to the resources of the babylonians how great they are
column3: i shall show by many other proofs and among them also by this:—for the support of the great king and his army
column4: apart from the regular tribute the whole land of which he is ruler has been distributed into portions. now whereas twelve months go to make up the year
column5: for four of these he has his support from the territory of babylon
column6: and for the remaining eight months from the whole of the rest of asia; thus the assyrian land is in regard to resources the third part of all asia: and the government
column7: or satrapy as it is called by the persians
column8: of this territory is of all the governments by far the best; seeing that when tritantaichmes son of artabazos had this province from the king
column9: there came in to him every day an artab full of silver coin (now the artab is a persian measure and holds more than the medimnos of attica 197 by three attic choinikes); and of horses he had in this province as his private property
column10: apart from the horses for use in war
column11: eight hundred stallions and sixteen thousand mares
column12: for each of these stallions served twenty mares: of indian hounds moreover such a vast number were kept that four large villages in the plain
column13: being free from other contributions
column14: had been appointed to provide food for the hounds.

column1: 193. such was the wealth which belonged to the ruler of babylon. now the land of the assyrians has but little rain; and this little gives nourishment to the root of the corn
column2: but the crop is ripened and the ear comes on by the help of watering from the river
column3: not as in egypt by the coming up of the river itself over the fields
column4: but the crop is watered by hand or with swing-buckets. for the whole babylonian territory like the egyptian is cut up into channels
column5: and the largest of the channels is navigable for ships and runs in the direction of the sunrising in winter from the euphrates to another river
column6: namely the tigris
column7: along the bank of which lay the city of nineveh. this territory is of all that we know the best by far for producing corn: 198 as to trees
column8: 199 it does not even attempt to bear them
column9: either fig or vine or olive
column10: but for producing corn it is so good that it returns as much as two-hundred-fold for the average
column11: and when it bears at its best it produces three-hundred-fold. the leaves of the wheat and barley there grow to be full four fingers broad; and from millet and sesame seed how large a tree grows
column12: i know myself but shall not record
column13: being well aware that even what has already been said relating to the crops produced has been enough to cause disbelief in those who have not visited the babylonian land. they use no oil of olives
column14: but only that which they make of sesame seed; and they have date-palms growing over all the plain
column15: most of them fruit-bearing
column16: of which they make both solid food and wine and honey; and to these they attend in the same manner as to fig-trees
column17: and in particular they take the fruit of those palms which the hellenes call male-palms
column18: and tie them upon the date-bearing palms
column19: so that their gall-fly may enter into the date and ripen it and that the fruit of the palm may not fall off: for the male-palm produces gall-flies in its fruit just as the wild-fig does.

column1: 194. but the greatest marvel of all the things in the land after the city itself
column2: to my mind is this which i am about to tell: their boats
column3: those i mean which go down the river to babylon
column4: are round and all of leather: for they make ribs for them of willow which they cut in the land of the armenians who dwell above the assyrians
column5: and round these they stretch hides which serve as a covering outside by way of hull
column6: not making broad the stern nor gathering in the prow to a point
column7: but making the boats round like a shield: and after that they stow the whole boat with straw and suffer it to be carried down the stream full of cargo; and for the most part these boats bring down casks of palm-wood 200 filled with wine. the boat is kept straight by two steering-oars and two men standing upright
column8: and the man inside pulls his oar while the man outside pushes. 201 these vessels are made both of very large size and also smaller
column9: the largest of them having a burden of as much as five thousand talents' weight; 202and in each one there is a live ass
column10: and in those of larger size several. so when they have arrived at babylon in their voyage and have disposed of their cargo
column11: they sell by auction the ribs of the boat and all the straw
column12: but they pack the hides upon their asses and drive them off to armenia: for up the stream of the river it is not possible by any means to sail
column13: owing to the swiftness of the current; and for this reason they make their boats not of timber but of hides. then when they have come back to the land of the armenians
column14: driving their asses with them
column15: they make other boats in the same manner.

column1: 195. such are their boats; and the following is the manner of dress which they use
column2: namely a linen tunic reaching to the feet
column3: and over this they put on another of wool
column4: and then a white mantle thrown round
column5: while they have shoes of a native fashion rather like the boeotian slippers. they wear their hair long and bind their heads round with fillets
column6: 203 and they are anointed over the whole of their body with perfumes. each man has a seal and a staff carved by hand
column7: and on each staff is carved either an apple or a rose or a lily or an eagle or some other device
column8: for it is not their custom to have a staff without a device upon it.

column1: 196. such is the equipment of their bodies: and the customs which are established among them are as follows
column2: the wisest in our opinion being this
column3: which i am informed that the enetoi in illyria also have. in every village once in each year it was done as follows:—when the maidens 204 grew to the age for marriage
column4: they gathered these all together and brought them in a body to one place
column5: and round them stood a company of men: and the crier caused each one severally to stand up
column6: and proceeded to sell them
column7: first the most comely of all
column8: and afterwards
column9: when she had been sold and had fetched a large sum of money
column10: he would put up another who was the most comely after her: and they were sold for marriage. now all the wealthy men of the babylonians who were ready to marry vied with one another in bidding for the most beautiful maidens; those however of the common sort who were ready to marry did not require a fine form
column11: but they would accept money together with less comely maidens. for when the crier had made an end of selling the most comely of the maidens
column12: then he would cause to stand up that one who was least shapely
column13: or any one of them who might be crippled in any way
column14: and he would make proclamation of her
column15: asking who was willing for least gold to have her in marriage
column16: until she was assigned to him who was willing to accept least: and the gold would be got from the sale of the comely maidens
column17: and so those of beautiful form provided dowries for those which were unshapely or crippled; but to give in marriage one's own daughter to whomsoever each man would
column18: was not allowed
column19: nor to carry off the maiden after buying her without a surety; for it was necessary for the man to provide sureties that he would marry her
column20: before he took her away; and if they did not agree well together
column21: the law was laid down that he should pay back the money. it was allowed also for any one who wished it to come from another village and buy. this then was their most honourable custom; it does not however still exist at the present time
column22: but they have found out of late another way
column23: in order that the men may not ill-treat them or take them to another city: 205 for since the time when being conquered they were oppressed and ruined
column24: each one of the common people when he is in want of livelihood prostitutes his female children.

column2: is this other custom which was established 206 among them:—they bear out the sick into the market-place; for of physicians they make no use. so people come up to the sick man and give advice about his disease
column3: if any one himself has ever suffered anything like that which the sick man has
column4: or saw any other who had suffered it; and coming near they advise and recommend those means by which they themselves got rid of a like disease or seen some other get rid of it: and to pass by the sick man in silence is not permitted to them
column5: nor until one has asked what disease he has.

column1: 198. they bury their dead in honey
column2: and their modes of lamentation are similar to those used in egypt. and whenever a babylonian man has intercourse with his wife
column4: and his wife does the same on the other side
column5: and when it is morning they wash themselves
column6: both of them
column7: for they will touch no vessel until they have washed themselves: and the arabians do likewise in this matter.

column1: 199. now the most shameful of the customs of the babylonians is as follows: every woman of the country must sit down in the precincts 207 of aphrodite once in her life and have commerce with a man who is a stranger: and many women who do not deign to mingle with the rest
column2: because they are made arrogant by wealth
column3: drive to the temple with pairs of horses in covered carriages
column5: and a large number of attendants follow after them; but the greater number do thus
column6: —in the sacred enclosure of aphrodite sit great numbers of women with a wreath of cord about their heads; some come and others go; and there are passages in straight lines going between the women in every direction
column7: 208 through which the strangers pass by and make their choice. here when a woman takes her seat she does not depart again to her house until one of the strangers has thrown a silver coin into her lap and has had commerce with her outside the temple
column8: and after throwing it he must say these words only: ""i demand thee in the name of the goddess mylitta"": 209 now mylitta is the name given by the assyrians to aphrodite: and the silver coin may be of any value; whatever it is she will not refuse it
column9: for that is not lawful for her
column10: seeing that this coin is made sacred by the act: and she follows the man who has first thrown and does not reject any: and after that she departs to her house
column11: having acquitted herself of her duty to the goddess 210
column12: nor will you be able thenceforth to give any gift so great as to win her. so then as many as have attained to beauty and stature 211 are speedily released
column13: but those of them who are unshapely remain there much time
column14: not being able to fulfil the law; for some of them remain even as much as three or four years: and in some parts of cyprus too there is a custom similar to this.

column1: 200. these customs then are established among the babylonians: and there are of them three tribes 212 which eat nothing but fish only: and when they have caught them and dried them in the sun they do thus
column3: and then pound them with pestles and strain them through muslin; and they have them for food either kneaded into a soft cake

column1: 201. when this nation also had been subdued by cyrus
column2: he had a desire to bring the massagetai into subjection to himself. this nation is reputed to be both great and warlike
column3: and to dwell towards the east and the sunrising
column4: beyond the river araxes and over against 213 the issedonians: and some also say that this nation is of scythian race.

column1: 202. now the araxes is said by some to be larger and by others to be smaller than the ister: and they say that there are many islands in it about equal in size to lesbos
column2: and in them people dwelling who feed in the summer upon roots of all kinds which they dig up and certain fruits from trees
column3: which have been discovered by them for food
column6: in the season when they are ripe and feed upon them in the winter. moreover it is said that other trees have been discovered by them which yield fruit of such a kind that when they have assembled together in companies in the same place and lighted a fire
column7: they sit round in a circle and throw some of it into the fire
column8: and they smell the fruit which is thrown on
column9: as it burns
column10: and are intoxicated by the scent as the hellenes are with wine
column11: and when more of the fruit is thrown on they become more intoxicated
column12: until at last they rise up to dance and begin to sing. this is said to be their manner of living: and as to the river araxes
column13: it flows from the land of the matienians
column14: whence flows the gyndes which cyrus divided into the three hundred and sixty channels
column15: and it discharges itself by forty branches
column16: of which all except one end in swamps and shallow pools; and among them they say that men dwell who feed on fish eaten raw
column17: and who are won't to use as clothing the skins of seals: but the one remaining branch of the araxes flows with unimpeded course into the caspian sea.

column1: 203. now the caspian sea is apart by itself
column2: not having connection with the other sea: for all that sea which the hellenes navigate
column3: and the sea beyond the pillars
column5: and the erythraian sea are in fact all one
column6: but the caspian is separate and lies apart by itself. in length it is a voyage of fifteen days if one uses oars
column7: 214 and in breadth
column8: where it is broadest
column9: a voyage of eight days. on the side towards the west of this sea the caucasus runs along by it
column10: which is of all mountain-ranges both the greatest in extent and the loftiest: and the caucasus has many various races of men dwelling in it
column11: living for the most part on the wild produce of the forests; and among them there are said to be trees which produce leaves of such a kind that by pounding them and mixing water with them they paint figures upon their garments
column12: and the figures do not wash out
column13: but grow old with the woollen stuff as if they had been woven into it at the first: and men say that the sexual intercourse of these people is open like that of cattle.

column1: 204. on the west then of this sea which is called caspian the caucasus is the boundary
column2: while towards the east and the rising sun a plain succeeds which is of limitless extent to the view. of this great plain then the massagetai occupy a large part
column3: against whom cyrus had become eager to march; for there were many strong reasons which incited him to it and urged him onwards
column5: that is to say the opinion held of him that he was more than a mere mortal man
column6: and next the success which he had met with 215 in his wars
column7: for whithersoever cyrus directed his march
column8: it was impossible for that nation to escape.

column1: 205. now the ruler of the massagetai was a woman
column2: who was queen after the death of her husband
column3: and her name was tomyris. to her cyrus sent and wooed her
column4: pretending that he desired to have her for his wife: but tomyris understanding that he was wooing not herself but rather the kingdom of the massagetai
column5: rejected his approaches: and cyrus after this
column6: as he made no progress by craft
column7: marched to the araxes
column8: and proceeded to make an expedition openly against the massagetai
column9: forming bridges of boats over the river for his army to cross
column10: and building towers upon the vessels which gave them passage across the river.

column1: 206. while he was busied about this labour
column2: tomyris sent a herald and said thus: ""o king of the medes
column3: cease to press forward the work which thou art now pressing forward; for thou canst not tell whether these things will be in the end for thy advantage or no; cease to do so
column5: and be king over thine own people
column6: and endure to see us ruling those whom we rule. since however i know that thou wilt not be willing to receive this counsel
column7: but dost choose anything rather than to be at rest
column8: therefore if thou art greatly anxious to make trial of the massagetai in fight
column9: come now
column10: leave that labour which thou hast in yoking together the banks of the river
column11: and cross over into our land
column12: when we have first withdrawn three days' journey from the river: or if thou desirest rather to receive us into your land
column13: do thou this same thing thyself."" having heard this cyrus called together the first men among the persians
column14: and having gathered these together he laid the matter before them for discussion
column15: asking their advice as to which of the two things he should do: and their opinions all agreed in one
column16: bidding him receive tomyris and her army into his country.

column2: being present and finding fault with this opinion
column3: declared an opinion opposite to that which had been set forth
column5: i told thee in former time also
column6: that since zeus had given me over to thee
column7: i would avert according to my power whatever occasion of falling i might see coming near thy house: and now my sufferings
column8: which have been bitter
column9: 216 have proved to be lessons of wisdom to me. if thou dost suppose that thou art immortal and that thou dost command an army which is also immortal
column10: it will be of no use for me to declare to thee my judgment; but if thou hast perceived that thou art a mortal man thyself and dost command others who are so likewise
column11: then learn this first
column12: that for the affairs of men there is a revolving wheel
column13: and that this in its revolution suffers not the same persons always to have good fortune. i therefore now have an opinion about the matter laid before us
column14: which is opposite to that of these men: for if we shall consent to receive the enemy into our land
column15: there is for thee this danger in so doing:—if thou shalt be worsted thou wilt lose in addition all thy realm

column17: but will march upon the provinces of thy realm; and on the other hand if thou shalt be the victor

column2: they wear a dress which is similar to that of the scythians
column3: and they have a manner of life which is also like theirs; and there are of them horsemen and also men who do not ride on horses (for they have both fashions)
column4: and moreover there are both archers and spearmen
column5: and their custom it is to carry battle-axes; 220 and for everything they use either gold or bronze
column6: for in all that has to do with spear-points or arrow-heads or battle-axes they use bronze
column7: but for head-dresses and girdles and belts round the arm-pits 221 they employ gold as ornament: and in like manner as regards their horses
column8: they put breast-plates of bronze about their chests
column9: but on their bridles and bits and cheek-pieces they employ gold. iron however and silver they use not at all
column10: for they have them not in their land
column11: but gold and bronze in abundance.

column1: 216. these are the customs which they have:—each marries a wife
column2: but they have their wives in common; for that which the hellenes say that the scythians do
column3: is not in fact done by the scythians but by the massagetai
column5: whatever woman a man of the massagetai may desire he hangs up his quiver in front of the waggon and has commerce with her freely. they have no precise limit of age laid down for their life
column6: but when a man becomes very old
column7: his nearest of kin come together and slaughter him solemnly 222 and cattle also with him; and then after that they boil the flesh and banquet upon it. this is considered by them the happiest lot; but him who has ended his life by disease they do not eat
column8: but cover him up in the earth
column9: counting it a misfortune that he did not attain to being slaughtered. they sow no crops but live on cattle and on fish
column10: which last they get in abundance from the river araxes; moreover they are drinkers of milk. of gods they reverence the sun alone
column11: and to him they sacrifice horses: and the rule 223 of the sacrifice is this:—to the swiftest of the gods they assign the swiftest of all mortal things.

column1: we make our way back to the carriage at the graveyard gate but the carriage is gone. dad looks around in the darkness and comes back shaking his head. mam says
column2: that driver is nothing but a dirty old drunkard

column1: it's a long walk from the graveyard to our room. mam tells dad
column2: these children need some nourishment and you have money left from the dole this morning. if you're thinking of going to the pubs tonight you can forget it. we're taking them to naughton's and they can have fish and chips and lemonade for 'tisn't every day they bury a brother.

column1: the fish and chips are delicious with vinegar and salt and the lemonade is tart in our throats.

when we get home the room is empty. there are empty stout bottles on the table and the fire is out. dad lights the paraffin oil lamp and you can see the hollow left in the pillow by eugene's head. you expect to hear him and see him toddling across the room
column2: climbing up on the bed to look out the window for oliver.

column1: dad tells mam he's going out for a walk. she says no. she knows what he's up to
column2: that he can't wait to spend his last few shillings in the pubs. all right
column3: he says. he lights the fire and mam makes tea and soon we're in bed.

column1: malachy and i are back in the bed where eugene died. i hope he's not cold in that white coffin in the graveyard though i know he's not there anymore because angels come to the graveyard and open the coffin and he's far from the shannon dampness that kills
column2: up in the sky in heaven with oliver and margaret where they have plenty of fish and chips and toffee and no aunts to bother you
column3: where all the fathers bring home

column1: the money from the labour exchange and you don't have to be running around to pubs to find them.
mam says she can't spend another minute in that room on hartstonge street. she sees eugene morning
column2: noon and night. she sees him climbing the bed to look out at the street for oliver and sometimes she sees oliver outside and eugene inside
column3: the two of them chatting away. she's happy they're chatting like that but she doesn't want to be seeing and hearing them the rest of her life. it's a shame to move when we're so near leamy's national school but if she doesn't move soon she'll go out of her mind and wind up in the lunatic asylum.

column1: we move to roden lane on top of a place called barrack hill. there are six houses on one side of the lane
column2: one on the opposite side. the houses are called two up
column5: two on the bottom. our house is at the end of the lane
column6: the last of the six. next to our door is a small shed
column7: a lavatory
column8: and next to that a stable.

column1: mam goes to the st. vincent de paul society to see if there's any chance of getting furniture. the man says he'll give us a docket for a table
column3: and two beds. he says we'll have to go to a second- hand furniture shop down in the irishtown and haul the furniture home ourselves. mam says we can use the pram she had for the twins and when she says that she cries. she wipes her eyes on her sleeves and asks the man if the beds we're getting are secondhand. he says of course they are
column4: and she says she's very worried about sleeping in beds someone might have died in
column5: especially if they had the consumption. the man says
column6: i'm very sorry
column7: but beggars can't be choosers.

column1: it takes us all day to haul the furniture on the pram from one end of limerick to the other. there are four wheels on the pram but one is bockety
column2: it wants to go in a different direction. we have two beds
column4: a table and two chairs. we're happy with the house. we can walk from room to room and up and down the stairs. you feel very rich when you can go up and down the stairs all day as much as you please. dad lights the fire and mam makes the tea. he sits at the table on one chair
column5: she sits on the other and malachy and i sit on the trunk we brought from america. while we're drinking our tea an old man passes our door with a bucket in his hand. he empties the bucket into the lavatory and flushes and there's a powerful stink in our kitchen. mam goes to the door and says
column6: why are you emptying your bucket in our lavatory? he raises his cap to her. your lavatory
column7: missus? ah
column8: no. you're making a bit of a mistake there
column9: ha
column10: ha. this is not your lavatory. sure
column11: isn't this the lavatory for the whole lane. you'll see passing your door here the buckets of eleven families and i can tell you it gets very powerful here in the warm weather
column12: very powerful altogether. 'tis december now
column13: thank god
column14: with a chill in the air and christmas around the corner and the lavatory isn't that bad
column15: but the day will come when you'll be calling for a gas mask. so
column16: good night to you
column17: missus
column18: and i hope you'll be happy in your house.

column3: sir. could you tell me who cleans this lavatory?

column4: she says. is it joking you are? these houses were built in the time of queen victoria herself and if this lavatory was ever cleaned it must have been done by someone in the middle of the night when no one was lookin'.

column1: and he shuffles up the lane laughing away to himself.
mam comes back to her chair and her tea. we can't stay here
column2: she says. that lavatory will kill us with all diseases.
we can't move again. where will we get a house for six shillings a week? we'll keep the lavatory clean ourselves. we'll boil buckets of water and throw them in there.

column3: and where will we get the coal or turf or blocks to be boiling water?

column1: dad says nothing. he finishes his tea and looks for a nail to hang our one picture. the man in the picture has a thin face. he wears a yellow skullcap and a black robe with a cross on his chest. dad says he was a pope
column3: a great friend of the workingman. he brought this picture all the way from america where he found it thrown out by someone who had no time for the workingman. mam says he's talking a lot of bloody nonsense and he says she shouldn't say bloody in front of the children. dad finds a nail but wonders how he's going to get it into the wall without a hammer. mam says he could go borrow one from the people next door but he says you don't go around borrowing from people you don't know. he leans the picture against the wall and drives the nail with the bottom of a jam jar. the jam jar breaks and cuts his hand and a blob of blood falls on the pope's head. he wraps his hand in the dish rag and tells mam
column6: wipe the blood off the pope before it dries. she tries to wipe the blood away with her sleeve but it's wool and spreads the blood till the whole side of the pope's face is smeared. dad says
column7: lord above
column8: angela
column9: you've destroyed the pope entirely
column10: and she says
column11: arrah
column12: stop your whining
column13: we'll get some paint and go over his face some day
column14: and dad says
column15: he's the only pope that was ever a friend to the workingman and what are we to say if someone from the st. vincent de paul society comes in and sees blood all over him? mam says
column16: i don't know. it's your blood and 'tis a sad thing when a man can't even drive a nail straight. it just goes to show how useless you are. you'd be better off digging fields and anyway i don't care. i have pain in my back and i'm going to bed.

column2: what am i going to do? dad says.

column1: take down the pope and hide him in the coal hole under the stairs where he won't be seen and he'll be out of harm's way.

column2: says dad. it would be bad luck. coal hole is no place for a pope. when the pope is up

column1: this is our first christmas in limerick and the girls are out in

column3: christmas is coming and the goose is getting fat
column4: please put a penny in the old man's hat.

column1: and if you haven't a ha'penny
boys tease the girls and call out
may your mother have an accident
mam says she'd like to have a nice christmas dinner but what can you do when the labour exchange reduces the dole to sixteen shillings after oliver and eugene died? you pay the rent of six shillings
column3: and what use is that to four people?

column1: dad can't get any work. he gets up early on weekdays
column3: boils water for the tea and his shaving mug. he puts on a shirt and attaches a collar with studs. he puts on his tie and his cap and goes to the labour exchange to sign for the dole. he will never leave the house without collar and tie. a man without collar and tie is a man with no respect for himself. you never know when the clerk at the labour exchange might tell you there's a job going at rank's flour mills or the limerick cement company
column4: and even if it's a laboring job what will they think if you appear without collar and tie?

column1: bosses and foremen always show him respect and say they're ready to hire him
column2: but when he opens his mouth and they hear the north of ireland accent
column3: they take a limerickman instead. that's what he tells mam by the fire and when she says
column4: why don't you dress like a proper workingman? he says he'll never give an inch
column6: and when she says
column7: why can't you try to talk like a limerickman? he says he'll never sink that low and the greatest sorrow of his life is that his sons are now afflicted with the limerick accent. she says
column8: sorry for your troubles and i hope that's all you'll ever have
column9: and he says that some day
column10: with god's help
column11: we'll get out of limerick and far from the shannon that kills.

column1: i ask dad what afflicted means and he says
when he's not looking for work dad goes for long walks
column2: miles into the country. he asks farmers if they need any help
column3: that he grew up on a farm and can do anything. if they hire him he goes to work right away with his cap on and his collar and tie. he works so hard and long the farmers have to tell him to stop. they wonder how a man can work through a long hot day with no thought of food or drink. dad smiles. he never brings home the money he earns on farms. that money seems to be different from the dole
column4: which is supposed to be brought home. he takes the farm money to the pub and drinks it. if he's not home when the angelus rings at six o'clock mam knows he had a day of work. she hopes he might think of his family and pass the pub even once
column5: but he never does. she hopes he might bring home something from the farm
column6: potatoes
column7: cabbage
column8: turnips
column9: carrots
column10: but he'll never bring home anything because he'd never stoop so low as to ask a farmer for anything. mam says 'tis all right for her to be begging at the st. vincent de paul society for a docket for food but he can't stick a few spuds in his pocket. he says it's different for a man. you have to keep the dignity. wear your collar and tie
column11: keep up the appearance
column12: and never ask for anything. mam says
column13: i hope it keeps fine for you.

column1: when the farm money is gone he rolls home singing and crying over ireland and his dead children
column2: mostly about ireland. if he sings roddy mccorley
column3: it means he had only the price of a pint or two. if he sings kevin barry
column4: it means he had a good day
column5: that he is now falling down drunk and ready to get us out of bed
column6: line us up and make us promise to die for ireland
column7: unless mam tells him leave us alone or she'll brain him with the poker.

column1: i would and more. you better stop the nonsense and go to bed.

column3: bed. what's the use of going to bed? if i go to bed i'll

column1: only have to get up again and i can't sleep in a place where there's a river sending poison to us in mist and fog.

column2: pounds the wall with his fist
column4: falls asleep. he's up at daylight because no one should sleep beyond the dawn. he wakes malachy and me and we're tired from being kept up the night before with his talking and singing. we complain and say we're sick
column6: but he pulls back the overcoats that cover us and forces us out on the floor. it's december and it's freezing and we can see our breath. we pee into the bucket by the bedroom door and run down stairs for the warmth of the fire dad has already started. we wash our faces and hands in a basin that sits under the water tap by the door. the pipe that leads to the tap has to be held to the wall by a piece of twine looped around a nail. everything around the tap is damp
column7: the floor
column8: the wall
column9: the chair the basin sits on. the water from the tap is icy and our fingers turn numb. dad says this is good for us
column10: it will make men of us. he throws the icy water on his face and neck and chest to show there's nothing to fear. we hold our hands to the fire for the heat that's in it but we can't stay there long because we have to drink our tea and eat our bread and go to school. dad makes us say grace before meals and grace after meals and he tells us be good boys at school because god is watching every move and the slightest disobedience will send us straight to hell where we'll never have to worry about the cold again.

column1: two weeks before christmas malachy and i come home from school in a heavy rain and when we push in the door we find the kitchen empty. the table and chairs and trunk are gone and the fire is dead in the grate. the pope is still there and that means we haven't moved again. dad would never move without the pope. the kitchen floor is wet
column2: little pools of water all around
column3: and the walls are twinkling with the damp. there's a noise upstairs and when we go up we find dad and mam and the missing furniture. it's nice and warm there with a fire blazing in the grate
column5: and dad reading the irish press and smoking a cigarette by the fire. mam tells us there was a terrible flood
column6: that the rain came down the lane and poured in under our door. they tried to stop it with rags but they only turned sopping wet and let the rain in. people emptying their buckets made it worse and there was a sickening stink in the kitchen. she thinks we should stay upstairs as long as there is rain. we'll be warm through the winter months and then we can go downstairs in the springtime if there is any sign of a dryness in the walls or the floor. dad says it's like going away on our holidays to a warm foreign place like italy. that's what we'll call the upstairs from now on
column7: italy. malachy says the pope is still on the wall downstairs and he's going to be all cold and couldn't we bring him up? but mam says
column8: no
column9: he's going to stay where he is because i don't want him on the wall glaring at me in the bed. isn't it enough that we dragged him all the way from brooklyn to belfast to dublin to limerick? all i want now is a little peace
column10: ease and comfort....

column1: mam takes malachy and me to the st. vincent de paul society to stand in the queue and see if there's any chance of getting something for the christmas dinner-a goose or a ham
column2: but the man says everyone in

column1: limerick is desperate this christmas. he gives her a docket for groceries at mcgrath's shop and another one for the butcher.

column3: no ham. no fancy items when you bring the docket from the st. vincent de paul. what you can have now
column5: is black pudding and tripe or a sheep's head or a nice pig's head. no harm in a pig's head
column6: missus
column7: plenty of meat and children love it
column8: slice that cheek
column9: slather it with mustard and you're in heaven
column10: though i suppose they wouldn't have the likes of that in america where they're mad for the steak and all classes of poultry
column11: flying
column12: walking or swimming itself.

column3: she can't have boiled bacon or sausages and if she has any sense she'll take the pig's head before they're all gone the way the poor people of limerick are clamoring for them.

column1: mam says the pig's head isn't right for christmas and he says 'tis more than the holy family had in that cold stable in bethlehem long ago. you wouldn't find them complaining if someone offered them a nice fat pig's head.

column4: but they'd never eat the pig's head. they were jewish.

column1: and what does that have to do with it? a pig's head is a pig's head.
and a jew is a jew and 'tis against their religion and i don't blame them.

column2: are you a bit of an expert
column4: on the jews and the pig.

column3: but there was a jewish woman
column6: and i don't know what we would have done without her.

column1: the butcher takes the pig's head off a shelf and when malachy says
column4: the butcher and mam burst out laughing. he wraps the head in newspaper
column5: hands it to mam and says
column6: happy christmas. then he wraps up some sausages and tells her
column7: take these sausages for your breakfast on christmas day. mam says
column8: oh

column10: and he says

column2: you don't have to do that
missus. if i had to do it

column1: mam says she has a pain in her back
column2: that i'll have to carry the

column1: pig's head. i hold it against my chest but it's damp and when the newspaper begins to fall away everyone can see the head. mam says
column2: i'm ashamed of me life that the world should know we're having pig's head for christmas. boys from leamy's national school see me and they point and laugh. aw
column4: look at frankie mccourt an'his pig's snout. is that what the yanks ate for christmas dinner
do you know how to ate a pig's

column1: grab him by the ears an' chew the face offa him.

column4: do you know the only part of the pig the mccourts don't ate?

column1: the only part they don't ate is the oink.
after a few streets the newspaper is gone altogether and everyone
can see the pig's head. his nose is flat against my chest and pointing up at my chin and i feel sorry for him because he's dead and the world is
laughing at him. my sister and two brothers are dead
column3: but if anyone laughed at them i'd hit them with a rock.

column1: i wish dad would come and help us because mam has to stop every few steps and lean against a wall. she's holding her back and telling us she'll never be able to climb barrack hill. even if dad came he wouldn't be much use because he never carries anything
column4: packages. if you carry such things you lose your dignity. that's what he says. he carried the twins when they were tired and he carried the pope
column5: but that was not the same as carrying ordinary things like a pig's head. he tells malachy and me that when you grow up you have to wear a collar and tie and never let people see you carry things.

column1: he's upstairs sitting by the fire
column4: which he loves because it's de valera's paper and he thinks de valera is the greatest man in the world. he looks at me and the pig's head and tells mam it's a disgraceful thing to let a boy carry an object like that through the streets of limerick. she takes off her coat and eases herself into the bed and tells him that next christmas he can go out and find the dinner. she's worn out and gasping for a cup of tea so would he drop his grand airs
column5: boil the water for the tea and fry some bread before his two small sons starve to death.

column1: on christmas morning he lights the fire early so that we can have sausages and bread and tea. mam sends me to grandma to see if we can borrow a pot for the pig's head. grandma says
column2: what are ye having for yeer dinner? pig's head! jesus
column4: that's goin' beyond the beyonds. couldn't your father get out and find a ham or a goose at least? what kind of man is he at all

column1: mam puts the head in the pot
column3: and while the pig is boiling away dad takes malachy and me to mass at the redemptorist church. it's warm in the church and sweet with flowers and incense and candles. he takes us to see the baby jesus in the crib. he's a big fat baby with fair curls like malachy. dad tells us that's jesus' mother there
column6: and his father
column7: st. joseph
column8: the old man with the beard. he says they're sad because they know jesus will grow up and be killed so that we can all go to heaven. i ask why the baby jesus has to die and dad says you can't ask questions like that. malachy says
column9: why? and dad tells him be quiet.

column1: mam is in a terrible state at home. there isn't enough coal to cook the dinner
column2: the water isn't boiling anymore and she says she's demented with worry. we'll have to go down the dock road again to see if there's any coal or turf lying around from the lorries. surely we'll find something on the road this day of all days. even the poorest of the poor don't go out on christmas day picking coal off the road. there's no use asking dad to go because he will never stoop that low and even if he did he won't carry things through the streets. it's a rule he has. mam can't go because of the pain in her back.

column1: it's a long way to the dock road but we don't mind because our bellies are filled with sausages and bread and it's not raining. we carry a canvas bag mam borrowed from mrs. hannon next door and mam is right
column2: there is no one on the dock road. the poor are all at home having pig's head or maybe a goose and we have the dock road to ourselves. we find bits of coal and turf stuck in cracks on the road and in the walls of the coal yards. we find bits of paper and cardboard that will be useful in starting the fire again. we're wandering around trying to fill the bag

column1: when pa keating comes along. he must have washed himself for christmas because he's not as black as he was when eugene died. he wants to know what we're doing with that bag and when malachy tells him he says
column3: mary and holy st. joseph! christmas day and ye don't have a fire for yeer pig's head. that's a bloody disgrace.

column1: he takes us to south's pub
column2: which is not supposed to be open
column3: but he's a regular customer and there's a back door for men who want their pint to celebrate the birthday of the baby jesus above in the crib. he orders his pint and lemonade for us and asks the man if there's any chance of getting a few lumps of coal. the man says he's been serving drink for twenty-seven years and nobody ever asked him for coal before. pa says it would be a favor and the man says if pa asked for the moon he'd fly up and bring it back. the man leads us to the coal hole under the stairs and tells us take what we can carry. it's real coal and not bits from the dock road and if we can't carry it we can drag it along the ground.

column1: it takes us a long time to go from south's pub to barrack hill because of a hole in the bag. i pull the bag and it's malachy's job to pick up the lumps that fall through the hole and put them back again. then it starts to rain and we can't stand in a doorway till it passes because we have that coal and it's leaving a black trail along the pavement and malachy is turning black from picking up the lumps
column2: pushing them into the bag and wiping the rain from his face with his wet black hands. i tell him he's black
column4: and a woman in a shop tells us get away from that door
column5: 'tis christmas day and she doesn't want to be looking at africa.

column1: we have to keep dragging the bag or we'll never have our christmas dinner. it will take ages to get a fire going and ages more to get our dinner because the water has to be boiling when mam puts in the head of cabbage and the potatoes to keep the pig company in the pot. we drag the bag up o'connell avenue and we see people in their houses sitting around tables with all kinds of decorations and bright lights. at one house they push up the window and the children point and laugh and call to us
column2: look at the zulus. where are yeer spears?

column1: malachy makes faces at them and wants to throw coal at them but i tell him if he throws coal there's less for the pig and we'll never get our dinner.

the downstairs in our house is a lake again from the rain pouring under the door but it doesn't matter because we're drenched anyway and we can wade through the water. dad comes down and drags the bag upstairs to italy. he says we're good boys for getting so much coal
column2: that the dock road must have been covered with it. when mam sees us she starts to laugh
column3: and then she cries. she's laughing because we're so black and crying because we're sopping wet. she tells us take off all our clothes and she washes the coal off our hands and faces. she tells dad the pig's head can wait a while so that we can have a jam jar of hot tea.

column1: it's raining outside and there's a lake downstairs in our kitchen but up here in italy the fire is going again and the room is so dry and warm that
column3: malachy and i doze off in the bed and we don't wake till dad tells us the dinner is ready. our clothes are still wet
column4: so malachy sits on the trunk at the table wrapped in mam's red american overcoat and i'm wrapped in an old coat that mam's father left behind when he went to australia.

column1: there are delicious smells in the room
column5: but when dad lifts the head from the pot to a plate malachy says
column6: oh
column7: the poor pig. i don't want to eat the poor pig.

column2: if you were hungry you'd eat it. now stop the nonsense and eat your dinner.
wait a minute. he takes slices from the two cheeks
column3: places them on our plates and smears them with mustard. he takes the plate that holds the pig's head and puts it on the floor under the table. now
column6: and malachy eats it because he's not looking at what it came from and it isn't pig's head anymore. the cabbage is soft and hot and there are plenty of potatoes with butter and salt. mam peels our potatoes but dad eats his skin and all. he says all the nourishment of a potato is in the skin and mam says it's a good thing he's not eating eggs
column7: he'd be chewing the shells and all.

column2: and it's a disgrace that the irish throw out millions of potato skins every day and that's why thousands are dying of consumption and surely there's nourishment in the shell of an egg since waste is the eighth deadly sin. if he had his way
column4: never mind your way. eat your dinner.

column1: he eats half a potato with its skin on and puts the other half back in the pot. he eats a small slice of the pig's cheek and a leaf of cabbage and leaves the rest on his plate for malachy and me. he makes more tea and we have that with bread and jam so that no one can say we didn't have a sweet on christmas day.

it's dark now and still raining outside and the coal is glowing in the grate where mam and dad sit and smoke their cigarettes. there's nothing to do when your clothes are wet but get back into bed where it's cozy and your father can tell you a story about how cuchulain became a catholic and you fall asleep and dream about the pig standing in the crib at the redemptorist church crying because he and the baby jesus and cuchulain all have to grow up and die.
the angel that brought margaret and the twins comes again and brings us another brother
column2: michael. dad says he found michael on the seventh step of the stairs to italy. he says that's what you have to watch for when you ask for a new baby
column3: the angel on the seventh step.

column1: malachy wants to know how you can get a new brother from the angel on the seventh step if you don't have any stairs in your house and dad tells him that asking too many questions is an affliction.
malachy wants to know what an affliction is.
affliction. i'd like to know what that word means. affliction
column5: the world is an affliction and everything in it
column6: puts on his cap and goes to the bedford row hospital to see mam and michael. she's in the hospital with the pain in her back and she has the baby with her to make sure he was healthy when he was left on the seventh step. i don't understand this because i'm sure angels would never leave a sick baby on the seventh step. there's no use asking dad or mam about this. they say
column7: you're getting as bad as your brother for asking questions. go play.

column1: i know that big people don't like questions from children. they can ask all the questions they like
column2: how's school? are you a good boy? did you say your prayers? but if you ask them did they say their prayers you might be hit on the head.

column1: dad brings mam home with the new baby and she has to stay in bed for a few days with the pain in her back. she says this baby is the
spitting image of our sister who died
column4: and the gorgeous eyebrows. that's what mam says.

column1: i want to know if the baby will be spitting. i also want to know which is the seventh step because there are nine steps on the stairs and i'd like to know if you count from the bottom or the top. dad doesn't mind answering this question. angels come down from above
column3: and not up from kitchens like ours which are lakes from october till april.

column1: so i find the seventh step by counting from the top.

the baby michael has a cold. his head is stuffed and he can barely breathe. mam worries because it's sunday and the dispensary for the poor is closed. if you go to the doctor's house and the maid sees you're from the lower classes she tells you go to the dispensary where you belong. if you tell her the child is dying in your arms she'll say the doctor is in the country riding his horse.
mam cries because the baby is struggling to get air through his mouth. she tries to clear his nostrils with a bit of rolled up paper but she's afraid to push it too far up. dad says
column2: there's no need for that. you're not supposed to be pushing things inside a child's head. it looks like he's going to kiss the baby. instead
column3: he has his mouth on the little nose and he's sucking sucking the bad stuff out of michael's head. he spits it into the fire
column4: michael gives out a loud cry and you can see him drawing the air into his head and kicking his legs and laughing. mam looks at dad as if he just came down from heaven and dad says
column5: that's what we did in antrim long before there were doctors riding their horses.

column1: michael entitles us to a few extra shillings on the dole but mam says it isn't enough and now she has to go to the st. vincent de paul society for food. one night there is a knock on the door and mam sends me down to see who it is. there are two men from the st. vincent de paul and they want to see my mother and father. i tell them my parents are upstairs in italy and they say
upstairs where 'tis dry. i'll tell them.

they want to know what that little shed is beside our front door. i tell them it's the lavatory. they want to know why it isn't in the back of the house and i tell them it's the lavatory for the whole lane and it's a good thing it's not in the back of our house or we'd have people traipsing through our kitchen with buckets that would make you sick.

column2: are you sure there's one lavatory for the whole lane? i am.

column1: mam calls down from italy. who's down there?
what men? from the st. vincent de paul.

column4: thank you. they want to know why we're living upstairs. they want to know about the lavatory. they ask questions because big people can ask all the questions they like and write in notebooks

if i have to get up in the middle of the night to pee in the bucket i go to the top of the stairs and look down to see if the angel might be on the seventh step. sometimes i'm sure there's a light there and if everyone's asleep i sit on the step in case the angel might be bringing another baby or just coming for a visit. i ask mam if the angel just brings the babies and then forgets about them. she says
column2: of course not. the angel never forgets the babies and comes back to make sure the baby is happy.

column1: i could ask the angel all kinds of questions and i'm sure he'd answer

column3: too. i never heard anyone say they didn't.

column1: i sit on the seventh step a long time and i'm sure the angel is there. i tell him all the things you can't tell your mother or father for fear of being hit on the head or told go out and play. i tell him all about school and how i'm afraid of the master and his stick when he roars at us in irish and i still don't know what he's talking about because i came from america and the other boys were learning irish a year before me.

i stay on the seventh step till it gets too cold or dad gets up and tells me go back to bed. he's the one who told me the angel comes to the seventh step in the first place and you'd think he'd know why i'm sitting there. i told him one night that i was waiting for the angel
column6: you're a bit of a dreamer.

column1: i get back into bed but i can hear him whisper to my mother. the poor wee lad was sitting on the stairs talking away to an angel.
he laughs and my mother laughs and i think
column2: isn't it curious the way big people laugh over the angel who brought them a new child.

column1: before easter we move back downstairs to ireland. easter is better than christmas because the air is warmer
column2: the walls are not dripping with the damp
column3: and the kitchen isn't a lake anymore
column4: and if we're up early we might catch the sun slanting for a minute through the kitchen window.

column1: in fine weather men sit outside smoking their cigarettes if they have them
column2: looking at the world and watching us play. women stand with their arms folded
column3: chatting. they don't sit because all they do is stay at home
column5: clean the house and cook a bit and the men need the chairs. the men sit because they're worn out from walking to the labour exchange every morning to sign for the dole
column6: discussing the world's problems and wondering what to do with the rest of the day. some stop at the bookie to study the form and place a shilling or two on a sure thing. some spend hours in the carnegie library reading english and irish newspapers. a man on the dole needs to keep up with things because all the other men on the dole are experts on what's going on in the world. a man on the dole must be ready in case another man on the dole brings up hitler or mussolini or the terrible state of the chinese millions. a man on the dole goes home after a day with the bookie or the newspaper and his wife will not begrudge him a few minutes with the ease and peace of his cigarette and his tea and time to sit in his chair and think of the world.

column1: easter is better than christmas because dad takes us to the redemptorist church where all the priests wear white and sing. they're happy because our lord is in heaven. i ask dad if the baby in the crib is dead and he says
column3: he was thirty-three when he died and there he is
column4: hanging on the cross. i don't understand how he grew up so fast that he's hanging there with a hat made of thorns and blood everywhere
column6: his hands
column7: his feet
column8: and a big hole near his belly.

column1: dad gets his first job in limerick at the cement factory and mam is happy. she won't have to stand in the queue at the st. vincent de paul society asking for clothes and boots for malachy and me. she says it's not begging
column3: but dad says it's begging and shameful. mam says she can now pay off the few pounds she owes at kathleen o'connell's shop and she can pay back what she owes her own mother. she hates to be under obligation to anyone

column1: the cement factory is miles outside limerick and that means dad has to be out of the house by six in the morning. he doesn't mind because he's used to the long walks. the night before mam makes him a flask of tea
column3: a hard-boiled egg. she feels sorry for him the way he has to walk three miles out and three miles back. a bicycle would be handy but you'd have to be working a year for the price of it.

column1: friday is payday and mam is out of the bed early

column1: there isn't much to clean in the house. she sweeps the kitchen floor and the floor of italy upstairs. she washes the four jam jars we use for mugs. she says if dad's job lasts we'll get proper cups and maybe saucers and some day
column2: with the help of god and his blessed mother
column3: we'll have sheets on the bed and if we save a long time a blanket or two instead of those old coats which people must have left behind during the great famine. she boils water and washes the rags that keep michael from shitting all over the pram and the house itself. oh
column5: we'll have a lovely tea when your pop brings home the wages tonight.

column1: pop. she's in a good mood.

sirens and whistles go off all over the city when the men finish work at half-past five. malachy and i are excited because we know that when your father works and brings home the wages you get the friday penny. we know this from other boys whose fathers work and we know that after your tea you can go to kathleen o'connell's shop and buy sweets. if your mother is in a good mood she might even give you tuppence to go to the lyric cinema the next day to see a film with james cagney.
the men who work in factories and shops in the city are coming into the lanes to have their supper
column2: wash themselves and go to the pub. the women go to the films at the coliseum or the lyric cinema. they buy sweets and wild woodbine cigarettes and if their husbands are working a long time they treat themselves to boxes of black magic chocolates. they love the romance films and they have a great time crying their eyes out when there's an unhappy ending or a handsome lover goes away to be shot by hindus and other non-catholics.

column1: we have to wait a long time for dad to walk the miles from the cement factory. we can't have our tea till he's home and that's very hard because you smell the cooking of other families in the lane. mam says it's a good thing payday is friday when you can't eat meat because the smell of bacon or sausages in other houses would drive her out of her mind. we can still have bread and cheese and a nice jam jar of tea with lashings of milk and sugar and what more do you want?
the women are gone to the cinemas
column2: the men are in the pubs
column3: and still dad isn't home. mam says it's a long way to the cement factory even if he's a fast walker. she says that but her eyes are watery and she's not singing anymore. she's sitting by the fire smoking a wild woodbine she got on credit from kathleen o'connell. the fag is the only luxury she has and she'll never forget kathleen for her goodness. she doesn't know how long she can keep the water boiling in this kettle. there's no use making the tea till dad gets home because it will be stewed
column5: boiled and unfit to drink. malachy says he's hungry and she gives him a piece of bread and cheese to keep him going. she says
column6: this job could be

the darkness is in the lane and we have to light a candle. she has to give us our tea and bread and cheese because we're so hungry we can't wait another minute. she sits at the table

column1: the master says we're each to bring threepence for the first communion catechism with the green cover. the catechism has all the questions and answers we have to know by heart before we can receive first communion. older boys in the fifth class have the thick confirmation catechism with the red cover and that costs sixpence. i'd love to be big and important and parade around with the red confirmation catechism but i don't think i'll live that long the way i'm expected to die for this or that. i want to ask why there are so many big people who haven't died for ireland or the faith but i know if you ask a question like that you get you the thump on the head or you're told go out and play.
it's very handy to have mikey molloy living around the corner from me. he's eleven
column2: he has fits and behind his back we call him molloy the fit. people in the lane say the fit is an affliction and now i know what affliction means. mikey knows everything because he has visions in his fits and he reads books. he's the expert in the lane on girls' bodies and dirty things in general and he promises
column5: when you're eleven like me and you're not so thick and ignorant.

column1: it's a good thing he says frankie so i'll know he's talking to me because he has crossed eyes and you never know who he's looking at. if he's talking to malachy and i think he's talking to me he might go into a

rage and have a fit that will carry him off. he says it's a gift to have crossed eyes because you're like a god looking two ways at once and if you had crossed eyes in the ancient roman times you had no problem getting a good job. if you look at pictures of roman emperors you'll see there's always a great hint of crossed eyes. when he's not having the fit he sits on the ground at the top of the lane reading the books his father brings home from the carnegie library. his mother says books books books
column2: he's ruining his eyes with the reading

column1: nora molloy knows my mother from the queues at the st. vincent de paul society. she tells mam that mikey has more sense than twelve men drinking pints in a pub. he knows the names of all the popes from st. peter to pius the eleventh. he's only eleven but he's a man
column3: a man indeed. many a week he saves the family from pure starvation. he borrows a handcart from aidan farrell and knocks on doors all over limerick to see if there are people who want coal or turf delivered
column4: and down the dock road he'll go to haul back great bags a hundredweight or more. he'll run messages for old people who can't walk and if they don't have a penny to give him a prayer will do.

column3: is a great champion. he wins bets in the pubs by drinking more pints than anyone. all he has to do is go out to the jakes
column4: stick his finger down his throat and bring it all up so that he can start another round. peter is such a champion he can stand in the jakes and throw up without using his finger. he's such a champion they could chop off his fingers and he'd carry on regardless. he wins all that money but doesn't bring it home. sometimes he's like my father and drinks the dole itself and that's why nora molloy is often carted off to the lunatic asylum demented with worry over her hungry famishing family. she knows as long as you're in the asylum you're safe from the world and its torments
column6: you're protected

column1: you can tell when nora molloy is ready for the asylum when you see her children running around white with flour from poll to toe. that happens when peter drinks the dole money and leaves her desperate and she knows the men will come to take her away. you know she's inside frantic with the baking. she wants to make sure the children won't starve while she's gone and she roams limerick begging for flour. she goes to priests
column4: quakers. she goes to rank's flour mills and begs for the sweepings from the floor. she bakes day and night. peter begs her to stop but she screams
column5: this is what comes of drinking the dole. he tells her the bread will only go stale. there's no use talking to her. bake bake bake. if she had the money she'd bake all the flour in limerick and regions beyond. if the men didn't come from the lunatic asylum to take her away she'd bake till she fell to the floor.

column1: the children stuff themselves with so much bread people in the lane say they're looking like loaves. still the bread goes stale and mikey is so bothered by the waste he talks to a rich woman with a cookbook and she tells him make bread pudding. he boils the hard bread in water and sour milk and throws in a cup of sugar and his brother loves it even if that's all they have the fortnight their mother is in the lunatic asylum.

column2: do they take her away because she's gone mad baking bread or does she go mad baking bread because they're taking her away?
